Throughout the 6 years in my life, I always wanted to play TF2. It was a dream game that I always wanted to play. I got the Xbox 360 version a while back, which was fun, but then my Xbox succumbed to the red screen of death. I also figured out that the old family laptop can run it (pretty slow though), until it didn't after a few weeks. But now, I can officially play TF2 for real this time, without any problems. TF2 is a wonderful game, even with the bad stuff such a bots, phobias, and other problems that plagued it; however, if you ignore all of it and play, you will love it. Thank you, Valve (especially Gaben).

[h3]First thought[/h3]
Well, on first impressions, it's a pretty good game. I played it a little, I want to note that there is a very good community here, I haven't mastered it very well yet, so my opinion will be supplemented.

Awesome game with memorable characters, beautiful artstyle, thrilling semi-serious gameplay and a passionate community... All watered down by a now negligent and greedy company that would rather passively monetise said community's passion than actually do anything about the game itself. Competitive mode is still broken, random crits still exist, tutorial and coaching system are as basic as they go but most importantly bots and cheaters, while a bit more managable now thanks to #savetf2, still run rampant. Of course it's up to you, but please, DO NOT invest money into the game that has been pretty much abandoned by its developers and now runs solely on content created by the community.

[h1] A Personal Journey Through Triumphs and Trials [/h1] 
In the realm of video games, few titles manage to carve a niche so deep in one's heart that they compel even the most reticent of writers to pen down their experiences. For me, Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is that exceptional game. Although I traditionally prefer playing over critiquing, TF2's rich tapestry of gameplay, community, and personal growth merits a detailed evaluation.

[h2] A First of Many Firsts [/h2] 
"Team Fortress 2 is the very first shooter game in which, as you may have noticed, I have spent a considerable amount of time and am actively continuing to do so." This sentence encapsulates my inaugural venture into the shooter genre, marking the beginning of an enduring engagement with TF2. Unlike any other game I've played, TF2 transcended its basic shooter mechanics to evoke a spectrum of emotions, from exhilarating victories to the bitter taste of defeat. My decision to financially invest in the game, participating in trades and navigating the community's economy, further solidified my connection to it. Witnessing the ebb and flow of its activity and being part of stories that unfold within its servers has been nothing short of remarkable.

[h2]The Double-Edged Sword of Engagement[/h2] 
However, no game is without its flaws, and TF2 is no exception. Despite the vibrant community and the endless hours of enjoyment it offers, the game is plagued by a persistent issue‚Äîbots. These unwelcome intruders disrupt the gameplay experience, especially on less popular maps, forcing the community to confine themselves to a handful of arenas. The inconsistency of the voting system adds to the frustration, with its effectiveness seeming almost arbitrary at times. Yet, these issues, significant as they may be, do not detract from the overall appeal of the game. They are but a testament to the ongoing challenges within its ecosystem, challenges that I hope will be addressed in future updates to revive and enrich the game further.

[h2]A Brigth Horizon[/h2] 
Despite these imperfections, my outlook for TF2 remains optimistic. The game's minor drawbacks‚Äîcheaters, scammers, balance issues‚Äîare overshadowed by its strengths. They stem from a larger problem of oversight, yet they are not insurmountable. I hold onto the hope that with time, Valve will breathe new life into TF2, ushering in an era of renewed excitement and updates.

[h2]In Gratitude[/h2] 
This review serves as an ode to Team Fortress 2, a game that has offered me countless hours of joy, camaraderie, and growth. "Thank you for the memories, Team Fortress 2." This simple yet profound statement reflects the deep gratitude I feel for the game. It's a reminder of the powerful impact a well-crafted game can have on its players, offering not just a means of entertainment, but a canvas for memorable experiences, friendships, and personal development.

In conclusion, Team Fortress 2 stands out not just as a game, but as a journey‚Äîa journey filled with highs and lows, challenges and triumphs. It's a testament to the enduring appeal of good game design and the strength of its community. Despite its flaws, TF2 remains a beloved title, worthy of both critique and celebration. Here's to many more years of capturing points, pushing carts, and making memories.

Team Fortress 2 is a classic first-person shooter that is widely considered one of the best multiplayer games of all time. It is a fun and challenging experience that can provide endless hours of enjoyment for gamers of all skill levels. Team Fortress 2 was released in October 2007 and has been updated with new maps, game modes, and features over the years, making it an engaging and exciting game even today.

One of the best aspects of Team Fortress 2 is its class system. Players can choose between nine different classes, each with their own unique abilities, weapons, and play styles. For example, the Soldier class is a highly effective offensive class that can deal massive amounts of damage with its rocket launcher, while the Medic class is a support class that can heal and buff allies. Not only do the classes provide a sense of individuality and diversity, but they also encourage teamwork and cooperation, as each class is designed to function together to achieve victory.

In addition to the class system, another aspect of Team Fortress 2 that makes it so much fun to play is the wide array of game modes available. From the traditional multiplayer modes like Capture the Flag and Attack/Defence, to the more unique modes like Mann vs. Machine and Pass Time, there is something for everyone. Each mode offers its own unique challenges and play styles, and there is always a sense of excitement and tension as players work together to achieve their objectives.

Team Fortress 2 also features a variety of maps, each with its own distinct design and gameplay dynamics. From the wide-open spaces of Dustbowl to the cramped hallways of 2Fort, players are faced with constantly shifting environments that demand quick thinking and adaptability. This variety of maps keeps the game fresh and helps players improve their skills.

One of the most challenging aspects of Team Fortress 2 is its high skill ceiling. Players who are just starting out will find that the game can be quite unforgiving, with experienced players often dominating matches. However, the game is also designed to be accessible to all players, and inexperienced players can quickly improve with practice and dedication. While it may take time to become proficient, the challenge of mastering the game makes the payoff all the more rewarding.

In conclusion, Team Fortress 2 remains a popular and beloved game for a reason. Its unique class system, wide variety of game modes, and challenging play style make it a highly engaging and entertaining experience for players of all skill levels. Whether you are looking for a fun casual game to play with friends or a competitive experience to test your skills, Team Fortress 2 has you covered. It is a game that has stood the test of time and is sure to provide hours of entertainment. So, pick a class, join a game, and get ready to have some fun!

This used to be longer, but I figured reviews are only really useful to people who have never played the game before. With that in mind, I made it a little more brief:

16 years after release, Team Fortress 2 is likely the most popular it has ever been. 
While Valve has done a great job keeping the game profitable, they have very little to show for it. 

Official matchmaking is infested with cheaters. They're not even real players. They're bots that any random person can host on a whim. This problem has persisted for several years and will likely never stop. Their cheats operate at a level VAC cannot detect.

As a F2P player on official Valve servers, you will not be able to use the in-game chat. 
This includes commands such as pressing E to call out for a medic. The aforementioned bots don't face any restrictions and spam the chat freely.

Since the 2016 matchmaking update that ultimately facilitated the rise of bots, vanilla community servers have almost gone extinct.
The ones that remain are filled with sweats, and you are at the mercy of what they consider fun. Most matches will be a stomp and you'll only see a fraction of the maps this game has to offer. Enjoy pl_upward and koth_harvest.

Updates have consisted entirely of community-made content for several years. There's even a "community fixes" tag in the workshop and they seemingly just ignore it anyway-- It's very natural for Valve to establish something and not follow through with it.

TF2 is a genre-defining masterpiece that deserves its place in history, but it fails to provide an adequate environment for new players and Valve isn't interested in changing that. There's no financial incentive to improve upon the game, so they'll just stay the course.

Give it a look if you're curious, but don't stick around.

This cycle of abuse repeats its self regularly, each time Demoman promises me he‚Äôll quit drinking, that he‚Äôd try to improve himself and fix himself, but once he seems to be getting better something or someone will set him off and he‚Äôll spiral back into abusing me. At some point we shall have children, the DeGroot family needs a successor after all, during my Pregnancy Demoman will take it easy, stop drinking, and it almost feels like he‚Äôs getting better, but once the baby is born and begins to grow up. This cycle of abuse repeats itself till one of us dies, maybe Demoman hits me a bit too hard one day and I fall dead to the ground, maybe I commit suicide, unable to continue living like this, maybe I‚Äôll kill him, put poison in his food or drink and watch as the man I loved, yet the man who I hated, dies and I'm free of him at last.

Cannot recommend the game enough. Not for the sake of just gameplay. The modding community, the community itself as a whole and the entire idea behind TF2 are reasons YOU should play it. Wanna join a class-based shooter where each one differs drastically from each other and there's no real "meta" to how a game is meant to be played? Do you enjoy pop culture and wanna just fit in and be yourself? Have too much time and not enough cosmetic accessories to fit onto your characters? Tired of microtransactions in shooters and just wanna go to the market to not get ripped off for your choice in build? Well this is the game for YOU! We have game lore, community lore, youtuber lore, a history of consistent official support from a large part of valve and if you've ever heard of Source Filmmaker, you've also most likely seen a character from Team Fortress 2 in one of the animations. Whether you're here to binge late nights in community servers of minigames or you just have an hour to play capture the flag camping as sniper atop Famous MannCo Sponsored location Teufort as seen in the featured MannCo Sponsored magazines and brochures, we have plenty to offer for all walks of life. What are you still reading this review for? Get to downloading and join up for endless fun for the rest of your life! Give em hell boys! Last one alive, lock the door!

The current state of the game is a mixed bag. It's still worth playing, but there's some things you should know before going into TF2 in 2024.

The player base has a broad skill range, and often times you will run into people who are either just picking up the game or are overall mediocre. You will also run into people who have played the game so long and who know its mechanics so well that they are practically untouchable. This can lead to one sided matches with no real way to balancing them other than hoping that the auto balance puts an actually good player on the other team. Its really not uncommon to run into games where one team just can't win because 2-3 players on one team are killing 50+ players throughout the match. This inevitably leads to a snowball effect as no one on the opposing team wants to stick around, and so mid match you might lose 20% of your team just because no one on the winning side wants to jump over and is enjoying rofl stomping the other team. Bear in mind I'm not talking about competitive mode but casual.

Not only that, but sometimes people will not play to the objective or play classes that would make winning possible. You will have three snipers/spies on a team (irregardless of skill mind you) because instead of playing a class that can actually push the objective, they'd rather click heads and are too bullheaded to realize they're actively hindering the team. This isn't to bash good players who know how to make the most of those classes, but more towards the people who are unwilling to play a different class because that's what the team needs. It doesn't happen often, but its hard to have fun when you're the only high health class with a bunch of support classes which will amount to a 5+v1.

Bots are also an issue that plague servers, but its not as bad as people make it out to be. I would say 1 in 15 matches you will run into a bot/cheater, and the only thing for it is to either out play them (which is possible if you know how the bots/cheaters operate) until they leave, or leave yourself. Checking names using tab can tell you if there are bots, specifically the .gg series, but you'll have to find out the hard way with cheaters. I would advise against calling people cheaters as there are players who are just so good at the game that its hard to tell the two apart.

Maps are also a mixed bag. Some maps are good, some maps are shit. It's hard to know what maps are good or bad until you've played on them, but i recommend avoiding maps like 2fort, and finding maps that have a balance of both open space and tight corridors. Part of the skill in this game is knowing what the map is and how to use it to your advantage, and so learning the layout and what places are safe or death traps.

On the classes, i recommend anyone playing this game to play Soldier as their first class with just the stock weapons. Learn how to hit meatshots with the shotgun, you will need it for other classes like engi, scout, pyro, and heavy. Then once you've gotten used to soldier, then its a pick of pyro, demo, scout, and heavy. I say this because they're classes that you can do something in with low skill for the most part besides scout, who has a low floor but also a very high ceiling. Medic and engi are also good picks, but they're play style is different from the previous mentioned, at least for the low end of skill. Engi can be a front line class if you know how to use the shotgun and have the minisentry, but other than that he's not really supposed to be on the front lines and is instead there to make sure the team has a safe place to retreat to, off healing, and making sure you minimize walking time for your teammates with the teleporter (imo the most powerful building is that teleporter because you can win a game if you can keep your guys on the front lines more than the opposing teams). Medics on the other hand are hard to find and just as difficult to play if not moreso. You may not be killing many people as medic, but you will need to learn how to position yourself and honestly he's in many ways like a scout, just with nerfed offensive capabilities. Your main goal is staying alive long enough to build uber and heal as many people as you can. Spy and sniper are specialist classes that take time to learn, much more so than the other classes, and have the lowest floor of all the classes. It's not that you shouldn't play them, but that when you do you will make your team weaker unless you're one of the above mentioned untouchable players who know how the game works inside and out.

Game modes are also a mixed bag.  Control Points are a solid choice and what I would recommend playing your first time around. Payload can be both good and bad depending on the map. Advice on that one is to stick to the cart and don't be afraid to use it as cover and crouch. KotH is my least favorite because often times the tight map means that the enemy team can gather up and spawn camp you. Many maps make this easy to do, and its not uncommon esp in tight KotH maps. CtF can be a good mode, but many of its maps are designed poorly and lead to grindy stalemates. The misc modes are fun but often time you will run into friendly servers.

Friendly servers can happen spontaneously. They don't happen often, but they do happen. This is when both teams decide to just not play the game and just goof around. It's fun, and if you run into one of these, its nice to chill and chat with people. Late night servers have this happen more often, but they can happen anywhere and at any time. If you see someone dancing around, walk up to them and taunt, you'll dance too regardless if you have the taunt for it. Its best to leave those servers if its not for you as the community doesn't take kindly to friendly killers.

MvM and other co-op modes like v Saxton Hale are okay modes, and there are plenty of people who play them, but they tend to be either too easy, or too hard depending on your time and your own skill level.

Other than that, don't buy anything, and don't worry about having only stock. The weapons are reasonably balanced where it changes your play style more than it being an upgrade. If you are struggling with stock, but can play with an alt play style, it may mean you yourself have an skill issue and are using the alt play style you're familiar with as a crutch. Stock is very viable and and I encourage you to get familiar those first before relying on the alternatives.

Overall though it's free and has an active player base. It can have some low points, but sometimes you get those really great matches where you know everyone is trying their best and no team is set to win via the luck of the match maker. It's very much worth your time.

I remember getting my free2play badge all the way back in September of 2013,  "Even though you we're late to the party, you we're still the life of it!" is what it said and that made me feel so welcome despite being absolutely bad at the game. And here i am 11 years later, still bad, but with so many great memories.
This game is a Masterclass in character design and individual character personality. Every single one of the Scouts "quips" lives rent free in my head. 
Game is also a testing ground for great map designs and ideas with the workshop and the released development kit allowing aspiring creators a chance to throw their hat in the ring.
This game lives off of it's community and in every the game falls short itself, the community is there to pick it up and help you get through anything as well.
Incredible game, responsible for so many incredible memories. Do yourself a favor and start making your own.
You might be late to the party, but you can still be the life of it!

I love this game but do not play it, originally this review was very positive as I started back in late 2021 early 2022, but the game has horrible cheating problems with automated bots in official servers and on top of this if you are a new player it will be very hard to be welcomed into the long standing community with the uncertainty and chaos of this game community with little or no support from the developers.

The matchmaking is atrocious, VAC does nothing, the game is bloated and runs messy, competitive play is too high of a barrier for entry and there is no support from Valve.

I'm cashing out of the little bit of inventory I have, I recommend anyone else here should do the same, the developers apathy and the communities chaos should be a sign of a dying game, and I refuse to experience the frustrations this game brings me just trying to play it anymore. If you have maybe a few friends and make a private server, or even better a LAN party then you will have a great time, outside of that do not even bother with the games community, bot hosters, cheat creators and even Valve's team towards TF2 themselves, they all have wildly and vastly different goals and capabilities that makes the entire situation an uncomfortable, dystopian and anxiety inducing place to be.

This game is wildly fun if you can get the setup right, but for the everyday person who just wants sometimes to play for a few hours, don't even bother.

The bots still somehow exist in decent numbers, community servers are practically dead, the only 'updates' are reused seasonal events from previous years, and the only new garbage ever being added is crates with more items that weren't even made by Valve or the single developer they're likely holding hostage, but by the community it perpetually ignores. Even f I got something slightly wrong on those last bits, I don't care; Valve hates this game and its community, and we'll never know, much less understand, why.

I love this game, and probably always will, but I hate Valve with a passion. I've put thousands of hours into this game, and I don't regret that in the slightest; my only regret is not playing more when it was actually good.

this game is good and should set a stranded (well it has) for other games. it is mind blowing to see this game have a active player base for the past 11 years

[b]I'll put here a tutorial to cook rice:[/b]

You will need : measuring cup, water, saucepan with lid, salt, rice, wooden spoon and a fork.

Follow These Steps

 1.Boil water and add salt
Pour water (for every cup of rice, use 1 3/4 cups of water) into a large saucepan with a tight-fitting lid. Bring to a boil. Mix 1 teaspoon salt into the water.
    
2.Pour in rice
Add it to the boiling water.
    
3.Stir once, or just enough to separate the rice
Use a wooden spoon to separate any clumps. Don‚Äôt over-stir: That can cause the rice to become sticky.
 
4.Cover the pot and simmer
Be sure the lid fits tightly on the pot. Turn down the heat to its lowest setting. Let rice simmer for about 18 minutes, then remove from heat and allow the rice to steam in the pot for another 5 minutes.
    
5.Fluff rice with a fork
Just before serving, gently fluff the rice with a fork to separate the grains.

Tip: Don‚Äôt uncover the saucepan or stir the rice during cooking. If it‚Äôs done before you‚Äôre ready to serve it, place a folded towel over the saucepan, replace the lid, and set aside. The towel will absorb excess moisture and condensation, helping prevent overcooked and mushy rice.

WARNING! WARNING!

This game is the most diabolical trap man has ever created.  Like a drug, Team Fortress 2 will always leave you wanting more.  It is never enough.  TF2 will consume your soul and your life.  You will spend countless hours on matches that feel like 5 minutes long.  You have this little monster in your head that wants you to improve, to be friendly on 2fort, to try some wacky combination of weapons you haven't done in hundreds of hours.  "Just one more game" you say to yourself.  It feels like TF2 speeds up your aging.

There's this meme about how this game took 9 years of development before it was released.  THINK ABOUT THAT!!!  Imagine spending 9 years on a project having no idea whether it would succeed.  Most people today can't even bother spending 10 minutes on a history project in school unless its at the very last minute.  Was it worth the wait? Yes... but there's a catch. 

This game is very, very good.  I have made so many memories in the 1300 hours I put in (at the time of this review).  But I look back and wish I spent that time into something more productive.  Reading books, exercising, spending time with family, and now I'm heading into college and I refuse to live like this anymore.

You wonder why your creatively inferior friends play other trash shooters like apex legends, valorant, csgo, pubg, fortnite.   Games clearly made with the intention of profit and keeping players addicted rather than actually being fun to play.

You wonder why Valve is neglecting such a masterpiece.  It's crazy to me that I've been playing the exact same game for 1300 hours outside of seasonal community-made maps and the occasional bug fixes update and that come in a handful amount of times every 3-6 months.

You wonder why at times you're so bad at the game occasionally despite your hour count.  Go on reddit, steam forums, or anywhere else and you'll see people with such low respect towards themselves and their skill despite having hundreds or even thousands of hours. 

The amount of people I've seen with countless hours in TF2.  5000 hours, 7000 hours, 8000 hours, 10,000, 12,000, 15,000 16,000 20,000, 25,000...  It feels like I'm exaggerating or making this up but you will understand the more time you put into this game.  You don't gain ANYTHING from it but these people are attached to TF2.  Who even are they without TF2?  Where would they be without TF2?  Why do they keep playing TF2?

If you've read this far and you are considering playing the game or you are already playing this game, please take what I'm saying seriously.  This game is truly something else, in a good and bad way.  This probably won't be the last time I see TF2, but I want to live a better life.  TF2 has gotten in the way of that goal for too long.  Play this game with caution and don't let it take control of your life, especially your most youthful and energetic years, just for one more game.

Team fortress 2 was a big part of my childhood

Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is a team-based first-person shooter game developed by Valve and released in 2007. The game features nine unique characters, each with their own set of weapons and abilities, and is known for its silly and comical tone.

TF2 is a timeless classic, with a large and passionate player base. The game continues to receive regular updates and new content, keeping it fresh and engaging even after all these years. The gameplay is fast-paced and thrilling, with a variety of different game modes to suit different playing styles.

One of the most iconic aspects of TF2 is its character classes, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Players can choose from a selection of weapons to build their perfect loadout, with many options available through drops or in-game purchases.

Another great feature of TF2 is its emphasis on teamwork. The game rewards collaboration and communication, with players working together to complete objectives and defeat the opposing team.

Overall, Team Fortress 2 is a unique and engaging experience that continues to captivate players around the world. It's a must-play for anyone who enjoys first-person shooters or simply wants to have a bit of fun with friends.

Five Years and Three Months ago, I wrote a review that I still stand by. This was an excellent game that I cannot recommend enough to try.

"[i]was[/i]"


I didn't want to update this review. I still love this game, so so much. There is so much good to say about this game, from it's gameplay, to it's character, to it's visuals and to it's community. I think this is still one of the best things Valve has ever done, but I can't stand by while seeing the state that this game is in.

Team Fortress 2's state over the last couple of years has genuinely made me sad. It isn't to do with the game receiving substantial changes that ruin the balance like with Meet Your Match, but rather that the game hasn't received anything resembling basic maintenance that should be expected for a game that Valve is still receiving money from to this day, both through it's marketplace and through mass-key sales from updates that Valve occasionally releases every Summer, Halloween and Christmas. These updates aren't substantial but, honestly, for a game that's nearly 2 decades old... I would be fine with this. It keeps the spirit of community in the game alive and gives freshness to the feeling of this old game.


The problem is that everything else is crumbling around the game.

The Bot Crisis has been going on for years, but Valve made a firm and strong statement that said they'd do work and give updates to squash the bot problem. And we believed them. For a small period, they were good enough fixes to heavily decrease the bots. They weren't gone, but I commended Valve's efforts... but they didn't do anything did they? While I believed there was work behind the scenes, I'm not even convinced that any of the efforts they've made in the past 600 days since the [b][i]#SaveTF2[/i][/b] movement was towards the bot crisis.

It's nearly impossible to join a server in the current state of TF2 without it being nigh-unplayable. Bad actors using bots or hacks, spamming ear-rape music that deafens the players... it's insufferable. If Valve had any proof that they were constantly updating their ancient anti-cheat or are working on an update to take down this new wave of bots, then sure... but that's not what's going on.


In my opinion, if Valve isn't going to do fundamental maintenance to keep the game playable while still making money off it, [b]then they should officially drop support and close revenue streams[/b]. Not even a question.

Valve is making a lot of money out of an, as of now, unplayable game in it's intended form. Basic business practice says that they need to be responsible for the service they're making money from and not be hands off 100% of the time.

This is without mentioning the other recent event involving [i]Team Fortress Source 2[/i], a gamemode in the upcoming S&box toolkit that I was keep on seeing the results of, being DMCA'd in the past few days. For such a formerly pro-community company, DMCAing a project that had clear love and effort put into it... it's heartbreaking. If there was any word of hiring these passionate fans or allowing them official consent, sure, but there is no confirmation of this.¬†

If Valve cares enough about Team Fortress 2 to take down a project that had more effort put into it than the past 6 years of Team Fortress 2 being updated, then I expect them to actually put the sodding work into it and make it fun again. They're not going to do that though, won't they?


I'm saying this out of love for a game that has been a huge part of my life, existing for almost 16 of the 20 years I've been on this earth:

[h1][b]Fix your fucking game Valve.¬†[/b][/h1]

I'm done waiting to see what content you steal from the workshop and make millions off of while you neglect a project that has had generations of fans come to and enjoy. I'm done hoping for a chance that the "security fixes" finally rid us of the problem plaguing this game for nearly half a decade. I'm more aware than ever that you don't care about a fanbase that's singlehandedly making you more money than most other live-service releases today.¬†

I'm fully aware that, in all likelihood, people won't sit around and read this review, let alone a Valve employee that understands why I feel the way I do. However, if there's one person who agrees with my thoughts, feelings and sentiments on the topic, then it will have been worth it.

I love Team Fortress 2 despite everything surrounding it, I just wish I could say the same for the company who owns it.
I've genuinely never seen a developer care this little about their community.

-Extremely fun game that has defined the multiplayer FPS genre for well over a decade. Unfortunately I can not recommend this game anymore due to Valve's negligence to maintain even bare-bones support. There are many issues but the biggest issue is the rampant cheaters and bots that plague the casual servers that instantly kill you from across the map. 

-One such issue is the severe lack of content. The last major update to the game was in 2017 with the Jungle Inferno update. Despite that, Valve continues to release cosmetic cases every season and maps for people to play in(not even made by Valve, it's all community made) for them to profit off of. 

-Another significant issue is the common bugs that plague the game. These bugs range from purely visual, to game breaking. Such examples are horrid performance, random cosmetics/particles teleporting in the map, flamethrowers having busted hitboxes, melee hit detection being god awful, and spy disguises are broken(making it very easy to tell if a disguised player is a spy), making an already weak class even worse. There's a lot more bugs I haven't even mentioned. The fact my Ryzen 7 CPU/2070 Super GPU PC struggles to run 60 FPS consistently in a firefight from a game made in 2007 is inexcusable, especially for a multiplayer game that's still widely popular and profits for Valve!

-Lastly, Valve doesn't like the modding community it once nurtured. Team Fortress was originally a mod made for Quake and Valve hired the original developers of that mod for the Team Fortress series. As of today, January 10th 2024, Valve has taken down a free community made project(From Amper Software) of porting Team Fortress 2 to the Source 2 engine that looks and runs much better than the retail product. Old Valve would have hired Amper Software already, but this isn't the same company anymore. Also Valve is fully capable of porting TF2 to Source 2, they just did it officially for CSGO(Now CS2), and Dota 2 years ago! Unfortunately Valve refuses to do so, and won't let the community do it for them.

-Valve, if you're reading this, please give the attention this game deserves, you already do so for Dota 2 and what is now Counter-Strike 2. This game needs a Source 2 refresh more than Dota 2 or Counter-Strike(which you already gave to those other newer games), especially since the source code got leaked which has enabled all these cheaters/bots to get into every casual server. If the game got a Source 2 refresh, it would make it significantly harder to make cheats/bots, give the game a modern refresh to it's look, and make it perform well on anything newer than a 2012 laptop.

-I hate to say it but if these game breaking issues are not fixed, a lot of players will leave the game, myself included. It's a huge shame because it's my favorite multiplayer game of all time that has one of the most engaged and committed communities the gaming industry has ever seen.

In a land a long, long time ago, Team Fortress 2 would be a critically acclaimed first person shooter. Boasting its colorful characters against the dreary palette of the Badlands, this game offered to many a wonderful experience. Later updates would add cosmetics, weapons, and a ton of other things to sink your teeth into. Some of those updates are not as well viewed by the community as others, like the addition of crazier and crazier hats. In recent years, the community has felt somewhat negatively towards the team of developers and their updates for this game. Though, there is something important to remember...

We first saw those deranged mercenaries nearly a decade ago! This game has been alive and kicking for a long time, and I doubt that you will soon see a day where these mercs aren't defying laws of physics, common sense, and sometimes all laws in general. You won't find many other games with a soviet in love with a 300 pound minigun that he just lugs around like it's nothing. Nor will you find a quick-witted, caffeine-fueled Bostonian who dances around the battlefield, dodging rockets and bullets like a madman. This game is very outlandish, and incredibly enjoyable. Even after years and years of pushing a payload down a track to blow up the enemies... people want to come back, because although there's some basis and objectives for the game modes, you never play the same game twice. Every match is a total surprise. Even competitively, the 9 classes and variety in what you can play with, it will give you a new experience nearly every time you play.

Years of pushing a cart filled to the brim with explosives is a hard task. Thankfully, there are new faces, hats to wear, weapons to try, and a new experience to be had every single day.
Incredible game with an incredible community
The game is 16 years old, still getting updates, and the community is as alive as ever. TF2 has outlasted several generations of competitors by being unique, fun and consistent.

I always come crawling back to this game due to the pure nostalgia that is pumped into my system when I join old maps that I haven't played in oh-so-long, or if I am goofing around with friends or by myself. However, I could never recommend this game to anyone who is starting out.

First off, there is the Casual matchmaking. You wait ~5 - 10 minutes to get into a game, just for the game to either be filled with bots that obliterate any player who dares walk into it's sightline, or one team that is overwhelmingly stacked and completely steamrolls the other team. Either way, the server will often become empty due to people ragequitting, leading to a repeated 5 - 10 minutes queuing just for the same thing to happen over and over again.

As for the competitive matchmaking, Valve truly just does not care at all. You are forced to have extremely high-quality graphics as well as having a certain viewmodel on your weapon, leading to some serious FPS drops as well as issues such as your entire graphics config being wiped. However, not all hope is lost it seems, as there are leagues that offer players to play a seasonal tournament. Unfortunately, these leagues are not well run. From cheaters who play for multiple seasons before getting banned, to legitimate players getting banned for the silliest of reasons, the moderation of leagues is laughable at best, and unbelievably infuriating at worst.

As for the community, it is a horrifying combination of all of the worst players. From furries to racists, weeaboos, and pride-flag-waving freaks that you wouldn't want to have near your children. This wouldn't be an issue if it wasn't for the fact that the majority of the community is like this.

We receive seasonal "updates" that bring the same boring-looking hats to the game, as well as maps that would make you question if it was someone's first ever project. People are too busy adding "Tran S. Wrights" doors to their maps than actually making a quality-looking and fun-to-play map.

The final saving grace of this game is their community servers. They offer different ways to play the game, such as community-made gamemodes, training servers to help you improve, and if you prefer to play a certain gamemode or map, there are servers out there that run 24/7 certain maps and gamemodes. However, some of these servers are poorly made, and will spam you non-stop with their ads. This isn't too much of a problem, since there is a command you can put into your console to disable ads (cl_disablehtmlmotd 0), however some servers [b]FORCE[/b] you to enable the ads.

I would highly recommend putting time into other games, as there are plenty of games that could suit the different tastes that TF2 does. And most importantly, if you do play this game, do not feed into the hivemind of buying fancy cosmetics and shiny weapons that everyone else does.

Team Fortress 2 is a masterclass in game design and after 17 years still holds up perfectly. 

However...

Valve has not updated the game in a substantial way in over six years. They have largely left the game itself to rot in an onslaught of automated cheating on their official servers, providing the playerbase with only minor content updates consisting of entirely, while often great, user-generated content from the official workshop. I cannot recommend this game to anyone unwilling to commit a serious amount of time and dedication to it.

Even if you are willing to make this investment, interfacing with the grander community of this game is a mess in it of itself, as while a small portion of the fanbase is quite accepting of everyone's own identity, a lot of the community comprises of older-school fans who won't hesitate to be some of the most foul people you can find in any fandom.

I don't want to end my review of this game on a negative note, despite the rating, so here's some ways to still interface with this game and have a positive experience:

Community run servers are a blessing to the game, as not only does automated cheating happen far less frequently here, users actually have the power to punish said cheating, unlike on Valve's own servers. If you're willing to commit time to this game, the servers ran by YouTuber Uncle Dane, named Uncletopia. While these servers have on average players whom are far more skilled at the game than anyone considering downloading it in the modern day, they offer and extremely similar experience to what Valve's official servers should be offering, with minor changes for the better, such as class limits and a more free form system of map voting.

As an addendum to this point, the game's competitive scene is still thriving to this day, with community run competitions being the reason some still play the game at all. With formats like Pugs allowing less experienced players in on competitive formats, its as accessible as it has ever been to get into competitive play of this game.

Another way to interface with the game is to experience fan-created projects and recreations of what they think the game could be like. Two big players in this region are Team Fortress 2 Classic, and Open Fortress. Team Fortress 2 Classic offers a version of the game catered to people who enjoyed 2007 initial release TF2, with far more visual polish and custom content added on, including the cut VIP mode. Open Fortress, on the other hand, is a completely new game, only borrowing its visual identity and base design from Team Fortress 2. It is a 'Quake-like' arena shooter, focused on fast paced battle to battle gameplay and is a treat for people who enjoy the types of games that inspired Team Fortress 2.

However, these shouldn't be how players should have to interact with this game to have fun. The default settings are terrible, communication on official servers is hidden behind a paywall, and to even have a marginally good experience you have to work for it, and without prerequisite knowledge of everything you need to do to even enjoy the game in its current state, this game seems terrible. 

One must invest so much time into being able to properly experience a classic such as this, be it by spending hours configuring the game to even run as it should on modern hardware, by playing for long enough to get into even basic competitive play, or by downloading player made versions of the game of which aren't always active.

---

This isn't a joke review, I know I have close to 4k hours in this game and that's not including all the different mods/console versions I've played as I really, really, really love this game. It's been a staple of my teenage/young adult life, and there truly has never been nor will there ever be a game to replace it. I'm not recommending it because this game just isn't like it used to be due to neglect from its developers and the experience for a newer player is most likely to be abysmal. 

The game is infested with bots and cheaters as Valve, the multibillion dollar corporation with all the resources in the world, chooses to do nothing about it. Their way of "combating" this was butchering the experience for a free to play user by heavily restricting communication, instead of, you know, developing an anti-cheat that's actually worth a damn. 

But even then, I wouldn't mind cheaters that much if it weren't for the god-awful matchmaking system that's been stinking up this game since 2016 like a half-opened jar of rancid horse radish you forgot in the back of your cupboard since Bill Clinton's daughter got her dad's dick wet. Seriously, after all these years, I still cannot fathom a single positive thing it added to the game and we're reaping the consequences of it's addition as the bot/cheater problem wouldn't be anywhere near as bad as it is now if it weren't for it's inclusion. 

Even if you do get in a game that's absent of cheaters, there's still a good 80% chance that the game you join will be a complete steam roll either with or against your favor. Playing with friends and trying to introduce them to this game always goes south as it consists of: wait 10 minutes to be put in a match, wait another minute for everyone to join, have both rounds end in less than 5 minutes due to the teams being utterly stacked, wait 5 minutes for a map vote, then leave the game and re-queue for an additional 10 minutes anyways because half the server rage-quitted after last match. Oh, and pray to god one of your friends doesn't get autobalanced halfway through, as there's basically no way you can change teams unlike years before.

Because how you played the game before, you looked in the server browser, found a server that was running a map/gamemode you liked, joined with your friends, and if the game was unbalanced you could either manually join the losing team to help them, or have autoscramble kick in which worked at least half of the time. It wasn't perfect, but I 1000% prefer it over the utter nightmare that is modern matchmaking. It's not nostalgia either, a community made mod called Team Fortress 2 Classic has that old system I just mentioned and I can play that game for literal hours in a single day, something I haven't done with normal TF2 in the longest time due to how frustrating it is to simply get put in a match. I can't even really put my finger on it but this matchmaking system has been the WORST thing I have ever seen added to a video game and I think it's going to pre-maturely kill this game.

I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with this game's community, but at the end of the day I've realized if you play this in 2023 you're just going to encounter every flavor of manchild there is. Hope you enjoy playing with obnoxious furries, weaboos, racists, and pride flag waving weirdos you probably shouldn't have around your children. I guess there's nothing inherently wrong with having these people present in your playerbase, but if these groups consist of the majority, then that really says a lot about the absolute state of your game. 

We get "updates" every summer/Halloween/Christmas that consist of community made content with absolutely ZERO (0) quality control. I know the art style has been dead since the inclusion of paints in like 2010, but oh my god the new stuff that's being added to the game is almost inexcusable and quite embarrassing. I'm talking about cosmetics that have no regard for the intended art-style and throw team/class recognition out the window, maps that not only play like shit but look like baby's first project with the hammer editor being OFFICIALLY ADDED TO THE GAME. Valve literally cannot be damned to get at least 1 single person to check the quality of the content that's being included to one of their most popular IPs that rakes in tons of cash. 

So yeah, if you're a new player or somebody thinking about getting back into TF2, I wouldn't bother. I want this game to be remembered for it's stunning legacy throughout the early '10s, offering the most fun experience you could have online, and not the pathetic zombie that it is now. There's nothing like it, but there's a lot of video games out there you can waste your time with. Don't waste your time with this one. Save it for something more enjoyable and do not enable Valve's neglect by blowing your wallet on stupid cosmetic items.

This game has always been my default go-to since I was a preteen. I'm in my mid twenties now. As newer games started to disappoint and life got crazier, TF2 was still there through out it all.

I played a lot until I was wrapping up college, COVID hit, then I found myself sinking another 1500 hours into the game over the next few years.

Despite TF2 not having the full game play changing updates we've missed for a long while, shout-out to the community for keeping the content coming. I know its mostly cosmetics, maps, and v-script game modes, but hey it adds a new experience to the game that I think folks are going to have fun trying out as they release.

Bots are still here in casual, sad I cannot play casual but I've grown to just be accustomed to the community server browser at this rate. Most of my time is spent in Skial/Uncletopia. (If you see me in Dustbowl, its probably not my birthday. If you know, you know.)

I've met so many wonderful folks throughout my time here that honestly give me more incentive to come back to this wonderful game and wacky community.

While I don't think new-comers will entirely understand the appeal of this game as we long time players have with all of the game's current issues, I would still whole heartily recommend this game to anyone to try out. Its free, why not?

Talking about this game is one thing, but experiencing it is another. Download the game. You won't regret it.

So I uninstall it.
Then I reminisce about TF2 and re-install it after some time.
I play it, but there are a lot of cheaters and bots.
I continue playing it, until I finally get tired of the bots and cheaters which are in nearly every single match, usually more than one. Sometimes there are even servers just full of bots.
So I uninstall it.
And the cycle continues to repeat itself.

Illicitly manufactured meth is usually made by combining ephedrine or pseudoephedrine with other chemicals that are often poisonous or highly flammable. The mixture is then added to a solvent such as gasoline and heated to crystallize.

Because illicit methamphetamine production is not regulated or supervised, and there is no quality control process, any number of cutting agents could conceivably be added to the process to dilute the drug.

The heating process is particularly dangerous, as there is significant risk of fire and explosion. The waste materials left behind are also highly unstable and combustible. According to the U.S. Forest Service, 1 pound of meth produces up to 6 pounds of toxic waste.2

There are many detrimental health effects associated with operating a meth lab. Inhaling fumes during methamphetamine production can cause significant lung damage and other respiratory issues, while handling the various corrosive or poisonous chemicals can damage the skin and eyes.

‚ÄúInstant Meth‚Äù Process
The standard process for producing methamphetamine requires space. Meth labs produce quite a bit of waste products and involve the use of numerous appliances, such as pots and pans for heating, stoves or burners, hoses for ventilation, curtains or other blockages, so individuals from the outside cannot see what is going on inside. This process can be quite expensive and difficult to maintain.

In addition, these sophisticated laboratories can often be spotted quite easily by legal authorities who are on the lookout for them and present a serious danger for the individuals who work in them, due to the highly unstable process of making methamphetamine and the combustible materials used in the process.

Some users and manufacturers use a ‚Äúshake and bake‚Äù method to make meth, where ingredients are combined in a plastic or glass container and then shaken and heated. The meth is then extracted. This ‚Äúinstant meth‚Äù approach can also be dangerous, as the substance in the containers is very volatile and can explode, particularly when being removed.

The community is a mix bag, I've met some of the most amazing, nicest, and kind people. People who are fun to talk with, chat too, and so on. Anyway, 8.5/10. 2352 hours wasted on this funny tf2 thing and still counting.

Title: "Borderlands Mayhem in TF2"

Scene: Moze, Zane, Brick, Gaige, Mr. Torgue, Tina, Maya, Hammerlock, and Lilith are sitting around a table, each with their preferred gaming device.

Moze: Alright, Vault Hunters, time for a break. Let's blow off some steam with a game of TF2.

Brick: Oh yeah! I'm gonna smash 'em! Who's with me?

Zane: (smirking) I'm going Spy. Sneaky and stylish, just like me.

Gaige: I'm Engineer, 'cause I love my bots. Meet Deathtrap 2.0!

Mr. Torgue: Demoman, baby! Explosions galore! Kaboom!

Moze: Soldier for me. Rockets are basically my thing. Explosions, right?

Tina: (excitedly) Pyro! Fire, chaos, and giggles. Let's burn stuff!

Maya: (calmly) Medic for me. Healing is an art, after all.

Hammerlock: (British accent) Sniper, my dear. Precision and finesse.

Lilith: (enthusiastically) I'm Scout. Fast, nimble, and always on the move!

They boot up the game, selecting their classes.

Scene 1: The Battlefield

Moze: (playing Soldier) Rockets away, suckers! Eat my explosions!

Brick: (as Heavy) I'm the juggernaut, bitches! Meet the Fist of the Badass!

Zane: (as Spy) Sneaky time, mates! Nobody will see this backstab coming.

Gaige: (as Engineer) Deathtrap, go fetch me some metal, baby!

Mr. Torgue: (as Demoman) EXPLOSIONS! 'Nuff said!

Tina: (as Pyro) Burn all the things! Everything is better with fire!

Maya: (as Medic) Healing is an art, my friends. Stick close, I've got you. üåà

Hammerlock: (as Sniper) A precise shot, and they won't even see it coming.

Lilith: (as Scout) Zooming around, dodging bullets, you can't catch me! üî•

Chaos ensues as they unleash mayhem on the battlefield.

Scene 2: Team Banter

Brick: (shouting) Moze, cover me! I'm going in!

Moze: (laughing) You got it, Brick! Rockets incoming!

Zane: (mimicking spy voice) I've infiltrated their base. They suspect nothing.

Gaige: (to Deathtrap) Fetch that intel, buddy! Good robot!

Mr. Torgue: (yelling) EXPLOSIONS, EXPLOSIONS, EXPLOSIONS!

Tina: (maniacal laughter) Burn, baby, burn!

Maya: (healing) Stay close, everyone. I've got healing for days. üåü

Hammerlock: (calmly) One shot, one kill. Classic Sniper style.

Lilith: (running around) Zoom, zoom! Dodging bullets like a pro! üòé

Scene 3: Victory Dance

They secure the win and celebrate.

Moze: GG, Vault Hunters! That was some epic gaming.

Zane: (smirking) Clearly, my Spy skills were unmatched.

Brick: Explosions make everything better! High-fives!

Gaige: Deathtrap, you're the real MVP.

Mr. Torgue: (yelling) THAT WAS FREAKIN' AWESOME! EXPLOSIONS, BABY!

Tina: Burninating the countryside, burninating the peasants...

Maya: Good job, everyone. Healing was on point. üåü

Hammerlock: A precise shot is like poetry in motion.

Lilith: (grinning) Fast, nimble, and unstoppable! Scout for the win! üòé

They continue celebrating, sharing laughs and high-fives, immersed in the chaos of both worlds.

Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is not just a game; it's a vibrant and timeless masterpiece that has solidified its place in the pantheon of multiplayer shooters. Developed by Valve Corporation and initially released in 2007, TF2 has managed to maintain its relevance and charm over the years, thanks to its unique blend of fast-paced action, distinctive art style, and a community that is as passionate as it is creative.

One of the first things that strikes you about TF2 is its art direction. The game's cartoonish, almost Pixar-like aesthetic, is a breath of fresh air in a genre dominated by gritty, realistic shooters. The colorful and exaggerated character designs not only add to the game's visual appeal but also contribute to its lighthearted and humorous atmosphere. Each of the nine playable classes is not just a set of skills and abilities but a memorable and iconic character with its own personality, quirks, and catchphrases.

The beauty of TF2 lies in its simplicity. The core gameplay revolves around two teams, RED and BLU, battling it out for control of various objectives across a variety of maps. The game's mechanics are easy to grasp but hard to master, providing a perfect balance that caters to both casual players and those seeking a more competitive experience. The diverse cast of characters ensures that there's a playstyle for everyone, whether you prefer the brute force of the Heavy, the sneaky espionage of the Spy, or the precision of the Sniper.

The class-based system is a stroke of genius, fostering teamwork and strategy. A successful team requires a well-balanced composition, with each class playing a crucial role. The synergy between classes, along with the need for effective communication, adds a layer of depth that ensures no two matches are ever the same. Whether you're pushing the payload, capturing control points, or engaging in the chaotic and hilarious "Payload Race," TF2 offers a diverse range of experiences that keep players coming back for more.

TF2's community is another standout feature. The game's iconic hats and cosmetic items have become a cultural phenomenon, spawning a thriving economy within the game. The dedication of the community is evident in the countless fan-made animations, comics, and videos that celebrate the absurd and entertaining world of TF2. The "Meet the Team" video series, showcasing each character's personality and backstory, has become legendary and showcases Valve's commitment to storytelling within the game.

Despite its age, TF2's graphics have held up remarkably well, thanks in part to its timeless art style. The optimization ensures that even on modest hardware, the game runs smoothly, allowing a broad spectrum of players to enjoy the experience. The game's relatively low system requirements contribute to its accessibility, making it a title that can be enjoyed by players with varying levels of gaming hardware.

In conclusion, Team Fortress 2 is not just a game; it's a cultural phenomenon that has stood the test of time. Its engaging gameplay, distinct art style, and vibrant community make it a must-play for any fan of multiplayer shooters. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the world of TF2, there's always something new to discover, and the sheer joy of playing never seems to wear off. Team Fortress 2 is a true classic that continues to define the multiplayer shooter genre and remains an essential experience for gamers of all ages.

my name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

[h1]Team Fortress 2 - A Timeless Team-Based Classic[/h1]

[h2]Introduction:[/h2]
Team Fortress 2 (TF2), developed by Valve Corporation, has etched its place in gaming history as a quintessential team-based first-person shooter. Since its release in 2007, TF2 has garnered a dedicated player base and remains a shining example of how enduring design, humor, and a commitment to free-to-play can create a gaming experience that stands the test of time.

[h2]Distinctive Art Style and Humor:[/h2]
TF2's art style, characterized by its bold, cartoonish visuals and distinctive character designs, remains one of its standout features. The game's humorous tone permeates every aspect, from character interactions to weapon design. The clever writing and iconic voice lines contribute to a lighthearted and entertaining atmosphere that distinguishes TF2 from more serious shooters.

[h2]Class-Based Gameplay:[/h2]
TF2's genius lies in its class-based system, where players choose from nine distinct classes, each with unique abilities, weapons, and roles. The synergy between classes creates dynamic team dynamics, emphasizing teamwork, strategy, and adaptability. Whether playing as a nimble Scout, a support-oriented Medic, or a heavy-hitting Demoman, the variety of playstyles ensures that every match feels fresh and engaging.

[h2]Timeless Maps and Level Design:[/h2]
The maps in TF2 have become legendary, with classics like 2Fort, Dustbowl, and Badlands standing as testaments to exceptional level design. Each map caters to various playstyles and strategies, fostering a sense of nostalgia for longtime players while offering newcomers a diverse range of environments to explore. The timeless nature of these maps contributes to TF2's enduring popularity.

[h2]Weapon Variety and Customization:[/h2]
TF2's expansive arsenal of weapons adds another layer of depth to its gameplay. The ability to unlock and customize loadouts encourages experimentation and adaptability. The weapons not only impact individual playstyles but also contribute to the overall strategy of the team, fostering a sense of progression and personalization.

[h2]Community-Driven Content:[/h2]
TF2's community is a driving force behind its longevity. Valve's embrace of community-created content, from maps and cosmetics to game modes, has enriched the gaming experience. The Steam Workshop integration allows players to contribute to the game's evolving landscape, ensuring a continuous stream of new content and creativity.

[h2]Free-to-Play Model:[/h2]
TF2's transition to a free-to-play model in 2011 marked a significant moment in gaming history. The decision to make the game accessible to everyone, supported by cosmetic microtransactions, has contributed to its sustained popularity. The model showcases Valve's commitment to maintaining a balance between accessibility and revenue generation without compromising the core gameplay.

[h2]Evolving Updates and Events:[/h2]
Valve's dedication to keeping TF2 fresh is evident in its regular updates and seasonal events. The introduction of new game modes, items, and cosmetic items during events like "Scream Fortress" and "Mann vs. Machine" revitalizes the player base and adds an extra layer of excitement to the TF2 experience.

[h2]Balancing Challenges:[/h2]
While Valve has made efforts to maintain game balance, the introduction of new weapons and updates has occasionally led to challenges in achieving perfect equilibrium. Some weapons may be perceived as overpowered, requiring ongoing adjustments to maintain fair gameplay. Despite these challenges, the community appreciates Valve's responsiveness to feedback.

[h2]Conclusion:[/h2]
Team Fortress 2 is a testament to the enduring appeal of a well-crafted team-based shooter. With its timeless art style, distinctive humor, and commitment to community engagement, TF2 continues to attract players from all walks of gaming. Over a decade since its release, Team Fortress 2 stands as a shining example of how a blend of creativity, community involvement, and enduring design can create a gaming experience that transcends its initial release and remains relevant in the hearts of gamers worldwide.

Team Fortress 2 is, in a nutshell, a team-based FPS in which the Red and Blue team compete against each other with 9 different classes in various game modes.

PROS:
+ Free to play 
+ Many maps, gamemodes and tons and tons of weaponry and cosmetics, both official and community-made
+ Very beginner-friendly. Unlike games like CS:GO, new players have a very fair chance of beating even experienced players
+ You will get weekly drops of weapons (sometimes cosmetics too)
+ A huge interest in trading items via a network of trading servers and sites. Skilled traders can make profit in the form of real money as well
+ Tons of alternate gamemode servers like x10, randomizer, medieval, deathruns, surfing, jumping, trading, tons of workshop maps, etc.  
+ It depends if you consider this as a pro, but there's explosivejumping. It's so incredibly fun and there's over 500 downloadable jumpmaps and an active community behind it. At least a fifth of my hours in this game are spent on explosivejumping
+ TF2 uses the Source engine, a very comfortable engine and very easy to configure and save settings with 
+ Trading cards 

CONS: 
- The community can be kind of toxic and/or cringy at times
- Valve keeps adding more and more updates people generally don't enjoy 
- If you play TF2 now, you'll play with a lot of weapons that used to be different (usually better) in the past. Occasionally weapons get re-balanced and often break because of it

Team Fortress 2: A Timeless Classic
TF2 stands as a testament to the enduring appeal of multiplayer first-person shooters. Originally released in 2007 by Valve, TF2 continues to captivate players with its unique blend of fast-paced action, distinctive art style, and team-based gameplay.

Visual Style:
TF2's art style remains one of its most iconic features. The cartoonish, exaggerated characters and environments contribute to a visually appealing and timeless design. The bold and vibrant color palette enhances the overall gaming experience, setting it apart from more realistic shooters.

Gameplay:
The heart of TF2 lies in its team-oriented gameplay. The game features nine distinct classes, each with its own set of weapons and abilities. The diversity among classes encourages strategic cooperation and ensures that each match feels dynamic. Whether you're a nimble Scout, a heavy-hitting Heavy, or a support-focused Medic, TF2 offers a role for every playstyle.

The emphasis on teamwork is evident in objective-based game modes like Capture the Flag, Control Points, and Payload. Team coordination is key to success, and the game rewards skilled players who understand their role within the team dynamic.

Community and Modding:
TF2 boasts a dedicated and creative community that has contributed to the game's longevity. Valve's commitment to supporting community-created content, including maps, cosmetics, and game modes, has kept the experience fresh for years. The ability to mod the game further extends its replayability, allowing players to tailor their experience to their preferences.

Humor and Personality:
TF2 is not just about shooting enemies; it's about enjoying the quirky and humorous world created by Valve. The witty character interactions, humorous taunts, and memorable voice lines add a layer of charm that few games can match. The personality injected into the game contributes to its enduring popularity.

Consistency and Longevity:
Despite its age, TF2 remains relevant and enjoyable. Valve's commitment to regular updates, balance adjustments, and occasional new content ensures that the game stays fresh. The fact that it has retained a large player base over the years speaks volumes about its enduring appeal.

In conclusion, Team Fortress 2 is a timeless classic that has stood the test of time. Its distinctive visual style, engaging gameplay, strong community support, and enduring humor make it a must-play for both veterans and newcomers to the first-person shooter genre. TF2's ability to balance fun and strategy continues to make it a standout title in the gaming landscape.

In a land a long, long time ago, Team Fortress 2 would be a critically acclaimed first person shooter. Boasting its colorful characters against the dreary palette of the Badlands, this game offered to many a wonderful experience. Later updates would add cosmetics, weapons, and a ton of other things to sink your teeth into. Some of those updates are not as well viewed by the community as others, like the addition of crazier and crazier hats. In recent years, the community has felt somewhat negatively towards the team of developers and their updates for this game. Though, there is something important to remember...

We first saw those deranged mercenaries nearly a decade ago! This game has been alive and kicking for a long time, and I doubt that you will soon see a day where these mercs aren't defying laws of physics, common sense, and sometimes all laws in general. You won't find many other games with a soviet in love with a 300 pound minigun that he just lugs around like it's nothing. Nor will you find a quick-witted, caffeine-fueled Bostonian who dances around the battlefield, dodging rockets and bullets like a madman. This game is very outlandish, and incredibly enjoyable. Even after years and years of pushing a payload down a track to blow up the enemies... people want to come back, because although there's some basis and objectives for the game modes, you never play the same game twice. Every match is a total surprise. Even competitively, the 9 classes and variety in what you can play with, it will give you a new experience nearly every time you play.

Years of pushing a cart filled to the brim with explosives is a hard task. Thankfully, there are new faces, hats to wear, weapons to try, and a new experience to be had every single day.

Team Fortress 2 is one of my favorite games of all-time.

However, I cannot recommend it in good faith anymore in 2021, 2022 or 2023. Especially after the game has been neglected by Valve for so long and how deafening their silence has been on a lot of core issues regarding the game - and I am not just talking about the absurd cheating problem - I cannot, in good faith, recommend it anymore.

Team Fortress 2 was released in 2007 and to say it revolutionized class-based first person shooters would be a massive understatement. Hell, I'd say it was a bold-faced lie. For years after it was released it was nurtured and loved by Valve, with updates helping to further along the game's core concept and add amazing new additions, like Payload in 2008 and Mann vs. Machine in 2012.

One day everything just stopped. TF2 stopped being updated. Valve seemingly had moved on from it. Nowadays, every so often, we get a minor update or a minor tournament announcement on the official blog and that's about it. Update droughts spanning months (or [i]years[/i] if major updates are what you're thinking) are unfortunately way too common. You can use the shoddy Competitive Mode as an example of this. Added in 2016 during the highly-controversial "Meet Your Match" update, improved upon with a better ranking system in 2018 during an unnamed patch (the fans call it the "Blue Moon Update" due to the Blue Moon Cosmetic Case being added that update) and then...that's it. No updates whatsoever since then. No lifting graphical restrictions, no class limits, no map pool rotations - nothing.

Same thing happened with stuff like the ConTracker - an amazing idea that was executed very well and then...abandoned. It showed so much promise yet Valve threw it under the bus entirely.

The community's doing its best to keep this game alive and kicking, with projects like CreatorsTF and just big YouTubers choosing to host their own vanilla TF2 servers rather than play on the radioactive wasteland known as Casual Mode, and honestly that's how I play TF2 nowadays myself - I go to community servers and stick around there for a while.

It's so sad to see one of my favorite games of all-time being treated and abandoned like cattle. Team Fortress 2 doesn't deserve the way it's being treated right now, but until that changes - my advice would be to stay away. Stay away until Valve shows they actually care about the game itself and continue to nurture and expand upon it. TF2 has so much room to grow, so much untapped potential that it hurts to play it sometimes.

Before we get to the main part of the review, I would just like to say that I really REALLY enjoy & love the game, the negative aspect of review for the game mainly stems from the neglect of the game by Valve, but we get there when we get there.

The Good:
TF2 is a game with a low skill floor, but high skill ceiling. You can always find something to look at & improve whenever you're playing the game. Each class have their own "unique thing going on with them" that you can constantly learn and get better at to achieve good results. Soldier with rocket jumping, Medic with tracking enemy medic uber, Spy and trickstab, and the list goes on & on. This in return, will net you a long playtime on the game as getting good at one class is already quite hard in and of itself, but now combine it with the game other 8 playable classes, and now you have 9 classes which you can continuously strive to improve on either all of them, or try to master only a few select classes to their fullest.
or, you can straight up ignore all of that and just play TF2 for the heck of it. Most of TF2 players are really casual and laid-back. The addition of group and partner taunts only really add to the casualness and the laid-back nature of the game alongside TF2 other features such as ragdolls and random crits (while I hate the latter, it does definitely result in several funny moment on the rare instances where they are downright annoying). TF2 is like the few games where you can boot up a match, lost, and still be having a blast due to the sillyness of the game. You can sometimes even ended up queue-ing up for a match, only to witness the entirety of the servers just dancing around, eating sandwiches and in general just having fun. While yes, this is probably (debatably) not exactly how Valve envisioned the game to be played out back in 2007, these friendlies who aren't killing anybody are still unquestionably playing the same game as you, just in a different way. This results in TF2 matches being varied from one to another, you may get a match where everyone try their hardest to win, or you can be matched into a game where everyone just essentially chill and hang around. Even if you would to still play the game "seriously", you still wouldn't be able to avoid the goofy nature of the game such as being greeted with 3 spies and 4 snipers upon loading into a match, or laughing at new players who are playing the game (in a good, fun way, something something we were all new when we started), which avoid the game from quickly becoming stale. At the end of the day, it really is just something you ought to experience yourself.

A lot more thing can be said about the game, but to keep it brief, I will now go to

The Bad aka
GOOD LORD WHEN WILL THE HEAVY UPDATE COME OUT ALREADY:tm:
The game, despite boasting about how it is "constantly updated" in its description, isn't actually "constantly updated". While yes we do get the small updates here & there, it have been bloody years since the community have actually receive a proper, major update which adds in new weapons, or even just balance changes to the game despite the promise of an upcoming update for the heavy. This isn't exactly too much of a big problem due to the "replayability" nature of the game, but when you have been playing the same game for a decade old at this point and not exactly feeling like wanting to be the Ash Ketchum of TF2, it does make sense why a lot of players be leaving the game for Overwatch back when the "TF2 Killer" was still alive. Hey remember that game? The recent Summer update, which added in new maps are very much appreciated and I hope Valve will continue adding in new maps at the very least, but since it apparently even got delayed and all, yeah, I guess only time will tell.

The Ugly:
Bots who cheats in the game exist, they spin around and headshot everyone immediately the second they see you. Thankfully, most players can detect the cheating bots and kick them from the game in a couple of minutes when the votekick system actually works and allow them to. This is bad enough as it is, but unfortunately scummy piss-lover unloved players, also known as human players with cheats exist alongside hosted bot cheaters and they usually aren't as blatant as the bot cheaters who go around spinning and headshotting everyone due to them being bunch of coward pussy with fragile ego. They usually cheat in mostly subtle ways that most unexperience players probably wouldn't even realise that they are cheating in the first place. When your game have cheaters both human & non-human running around scott-free in the game due to VAC doing jack all alongside Valve lousy attempt(s) in fixing it (which was like, what, a year or two ago?) which ended up hurting new players more than it does the bot cheaters by disabling any form of communication on F2P accounts, I really have to ask, is it really worth it to boot up a game, fully knowing the chance of you ended up being matched with cheaters who oneshot you immediately the second you walk out of spawn. I don't think any logical & sane human would enjoy such experience.

Overall, it is quite a shame really, the game is very good, and amazing, and good, and fun, and superb, and good, but the ignorance coming from Valve is very disheartening. Remember #SaveTF2? Cool, whatever happen to that I wonder?
tl;dr Do I recommend the game? In the game current state, filled with bots & closet cheaters? No, god no, but if you were to ask me eight years ago whether I'd recommend the game or not, I wouldn't even have to think of it. Nowadays, I feel dishonest everytime I recommend the game to someone. How do I get people to play a game that haven't got (majorly) updated in years, with a majorly flawed anti-cheat to boot? Simple, I don't.

SANDWICH!

Ingredients:
- 6 slices of bread (white, whole wheat, or your preference)
- 6 ounces of cooked turkey breast, sliced
- 6 ounces of cooked chicken breast, sliced
- 4 lettuce leaves
- 2 tomatoes, sliced
- 4 slices of cheese (cheddar, Swiss, or your preference)
- Mayonnaise
- Mustard
- Salt and pepper to taste

Instructions:
1. Toast the bread slices if desired. This step is optional and depends on personal preference.
2. Spread a thin layer of mayonnaise and mustard on one side of each bread slice.
3. Assemble the sandwich by placing a lettuce leaf on one slice of bread.
4. Top the lettuce with a few slices of turkey breast, followed by a slice of cheese.
5. Place another bread slice on top and spread a thin layer of mayonnaise and mustard on it.
6. Add a lettuce leaf, followed by a few slices of chicken breast and some tomato slices.
7. Sprinkle some salt and pepper to taste, then top with another slice of bread.
8. Repeat the steps for the remaining ingredients to make additional sandwiches.
9. Cut the sandwiches in half or quarters diagonally, and secure them with toothpicks if desired.
10. Serve immediately and enjoy!

Note: Feel free to add other ingredients or condiments, such as avocado, pickle slices, or your favorite sauces, to customize the sandwich to your liking.
