When I first heared of TF2, I had to play it, but it was only on steam so I set a steam account for myself. It was F2P when I first heard of it, so I did not have to spend a single penny, It was the most addictive game I ever played, I played it every morning, it is super fantastic. The gameplay is fast, it's fun, it's original. There 9 classes with different stats, abilities, wapons and hats, don't forget hats. The updates on this game are really exciting, fixing bugs, new weapons, maps, hats, etc. If you truely want to experience TF2, you must spend some money to do so.Anyways, since TF2 is F2P, so the community is one of the biggest in Steam. expect alot of F2P kids who yammer on the mike, and take the game too seriously even though it's a casual game. The gamemodes are original such as the payload mode, Mann vs. Machine, Control Points. Some non-official gamemodes are popular in TF2, such as x10 where weapon stats are multiplied by 10, vs Saxton Hale mode, a mode where a team fights against a boss which is a randomly selected player to play as Saxton Hale or some other boss such as the easter bunny, Christian Brutal Sniper, Painis Cupcake, the Vagineer,  Bonk Boy, Demopan etc. Anyways TF2 is really fun, it's still a thing especially the game is over 10 years old now. Anyways play the game, in my opinion, a Steam user is not a real steam user until they've played TF2. If Steam had one game to represent itself, TF2 would be the choice.

Overall 10/10 find myself coming back all the time. Nothing new hits quite like TF2.

It's a great game. I can't say enough about it. However I've reached my limit. Over my 3 years of playing, I'd say that zero updates was the final straw for me. I've done a lot of combos. I've traded items and done a couple of trade-ups. I have physically exhausted this game. This is like my 3rd burnout (at time of writing). Over my time, here are some things that were good and bad:

The Good
- 9 classes, all varied. Some share weapons, but never primaries. The characters have the old Valve charm on them! The VA's did a great job with their lines!
- Gun play is great, with tons of weapons to try and use for each class.
- Maps are balanced (Valve made and early community maps are pretty good).
- It was made to be fun, not a sweaty game. 
- Somewhat of a time capsule.
- Tons of cosmetics, WE LOVE HATS!
- Decent community, amazing SFM content.
- Microtransactions are PURELY cosmetic ones. 
- Drop system grants weapons and cosmetics (the cosmetic drops are rare but servers freak out, its a different, but cool feeling).
- Its a time capsule.
- Sort of cartoony artstyle. 
- Hard difficulty curve, but you can overcome it with time. This is a con, however if you stay long enough you'll appreciate the game more. If you need help, check class tutorials on YouTube. They really help!


The Bad (aka Volvo Plz Fix)
- Bots, bots, bots. They're everywhere. Valve has actively done nothing to cheaters. They roam everywhere. HOWEVER that is region depending. The U.S. servers are just... atrocious sometimes.
- The racism is rare (in my experiences) but exists nonetheless. This is strictly a player issue. 
- Report functions don't work. Voting does however.
- NEED PREMIUM TO TALK (this WAS a F2P feature and everyone's feature) REASON: This was Valve's response to cheaters. Did it fix things? No. The bots still snipe you hard. However, no more ear-aching high volume racism or music. 
- Dead modes, specifically Versus Saxton Hale. PASSTIME is cool though, and I don't think its bad at all but its over here anyways.
- No recent balance changes. Heavy is somewhat under-powered and Sniper is overpowered (yes I am aware that people will say "skill issue" and ignore that fact that one good Sniper can wipe an entire team regardless of skill level).
- Updates are, as the kids say, MID. They are strictly seasonal. 
- I will not bash competitive MODE. I want to try it out so bad. But its usually dead. The community hates it, even though y'all helped its creation. 
- Some people want the old Valve matchmaking system back but old server menus are cluttered and confusing. Not against the return of Arena or Quickplay (every modern game has these modes).
- Very questionable cases and warpaints. Most are objectively crap. However, there are some good ones. 
- Microtransactions from ages ago are still priced high when you can trade for them cheaper and easier. 
- Most furries that play this game are weird. I mean, come on guys. CALM DOWN. 
- Figureheads in the community are usually fine, but some have drastically done things to the micro-society in this game and artificially inflated prices for many items on the market. 
- Old HUD and graphics options. (An easy fix is to look for something like MasterComfig for graphics, and there are many custom HUDs available on the internet so you can fix both).


My initial thoughts on this title are positive, however with three years of experience, I did find some negatives. Don't let this review confuse you; I HIGHLY RECOMMEND PLAYING THIS. But some decisions the devs made recently as well as the content not being as engaging have led me to take a hiatus. I'll come back soon. 



But just know that your first moments with this game, if you choose to stick with it... will be great.

I fucking love this game. I always loved it and will always continue to love it, but Valve doesn't share the sentiment.
It's been so long since I could enjoy a match without a cheater, bot army invasion or racial slurs being yelled in the voice chat. And I'm not saying that cheaters make the game less enjoyable, I'm saying that make it [b]unplayable[/b].
Getting killed the second you respawn, by a sniper spinning in place in front of the gates over and over while his team is refusing to kick him, this is the gameplay you will experience after downloading this game.
I always held hope that the game is still a masterpiece and it's just a string of bad events that make it less enjoyable, but no more.
I've played this game for almost 10 years now, haven't seen it updated in any major way except adding more micro transactions in 6 years. All the cosmetics added aren't even made by the developers, but bought off the community. Anti-cheat hasn't been updated since then either, because all Valve cares about is the money flow they get from dumb fucks like me who still love the game despite the fact the devs couldn't give less of a shit about any of it's players.
Spare yourself the pain, please. The game will lure you in with amazing gameplay design, memorable characters and free price, just to fuck you over for nothing except trying to love it.

How to Cook Rice: A Step-by-Step Guide

The Classic Method

-Rinse the rice.
-Use the right ratio of water. Add 2 parts water and 1 part rice to a large pot. For slightly firmer rice, use 1 part liquid to 2/3 parts rice.
-Bring the water to a boil. Once it's boiling, add a big pinch of salt.
-Maintain a simmer. Reduce heat to low, cover the pot with a tight fitting lid, and maintain a gentle simmer.
-Cook without peeking or stirring. Cook until the water is absorbed, about 18 minutes. Try not to peek until the end of the cooking time so the steam doesn't escape. Whatever you do, don't mix the rice while it's cooking ‚Äî this will lead to gummy rice.
-Let the rice rest covered. Turn off the heat and let the rice sit, covered, for 10 minutes. During this time, the rice will steam for extra fluffy results.
-Fluff the rice with a fork.

The Pasta Method

-Rinse the rice.
-Bring water to a boil, then add the rice. Fill the pot with water (no need to measure) and salt it ‚Äî just like you do with pasta water. Bring it to a boil and then carefully add your desired amount of rice.
-Maintain a boil. Boil uncovered without stirring until the rice is softened through but still a tad al dente (read: not mushy).
-Drain the rice. Drain the rice through a fine mesh strainer.

The Pilaf Method

-Rinse the rice.
-Toast the rice to complement the nuttiness. We love toasting all sorts of rice, but when you toast aromatic rice, the results pay off exponentially. Add 1 part rice to a pot with a dab of oil or butter and cook over medium until it looks toasted and smells nutty, 2 to 3 minutes.
-Bring water to a boil before adding it to the rice. Meanwhile, bring 2 parts of water to a boil. Pouring already boiling water on top of the rice helps control the exact amount of water you're adding, something that's important for basmati and jasmine rice because they're on the starchy side and can end up gummy. You're aiming to achieve separate grains.
-Simmer the rice. Reduce the heat to low, cover and simmer until the liquid is absorbed, about 18 minutes.
-Let the rice rest covered. Turn off the heat and let the rice sit, covered, for 10 minutes to allow it to steam.
-Fluff with a fork.

How to Cook Rice in a Rice Cooker

-Rinse the rice.
-Use a 1:1 water to rice ratio. This ratio applies to larger batches too. While it can be used with smaller amounts, the water doesn't absorb at the same rate, which could affect your end result. You'll have to play around a little with the cooker, using your manual's guidelines, to see what works best with different recipes and for your individual needs.
-Let the rice cooker do all the work for you. Press the "on" button and the cooker will handle the cooking time.
-Let the rice rest covered. Let it rest, covered, for about 10 minutes for fluffy results.

How to Cook Rice In the Microwave

-Rinse the rice.
-Use a large heat-safe container. A large bowl square baking dish works perfectly. Keep in mind that the rice will expand as it cooks.
-Use 2 parts rice to 3 1/2 parts water.
-Microwave on high uncovered first. Microwave until steam holes appear and a lot of the water has disappeared. If you're using 2 cups of rice, this will be for about 10 minutes.
-Microwave covered on medium-low. Use heat-safe plastic wrap and cook until the liquid is completely absorbed (about 15 minutes for 2 cups of rice).
-Fluff and season before serving. Use a fork to fluff the grain, seasoning as you do this

It's Team Fortress 2. Need I say more? Memorable mercenaries, lots of hats, balanced multiplayer gameplay, and a strong sense of community are what keep players coming back for more even after 16 years since it first released as part of The Orange Box.

Just one thing of the utmost importance: Stick with the community servers. Unfortunately, for over three years now, official matchmaking servers have been plagued with Sniper bots that have aimbot and will one-shot you without fail if they see you, all while spamming inappropriate things in the chat. The closest experience you can get to playing traditional TF2 without having to deal with these bots is through the Uncletopia servers (Courtesy of beloved Engineer main Uncle Dane).

Team Fortress 2 is a fast-paced, multiplayer first-person shooter with a vibrant art style and quirky cast of characters. Players can choose from nine different classes, each with unique abilities and playstyles, to engage in objective-based gameplay across a variety of maps. The game emphasizes teamwork and communication, making it a rewarding experience for players who are willing to coordinate with their teammates. While there are occasional balancing issues and glitches, overall Team Fortress 2 remains a fun and engaging multiplayer experience that has stood the test of time.

Team Fortress 2 is multiplayer team-based FPS, and is the sequel to Team Fortress, rebuilt on Valve's Source Engine and including a host of improvements over the first game.

I love this game (look at my profile picture), and have spent many happy hours playing as my favourite class, the Heavy Weapons Guy.  The cartoon-inspired depictions of the different classes are amazing and add to the character and humour of the game.  Each class has unique abilities and weapons that can perform different roles in the team.

Every so often I come back to this game to see what has changed.  It is free-to-play now, and that has brought both both positive and negative things to the game, but overall this is still an immensely enjoyable game to play!
A game that stands tall even 16 years down the line. Every class is a delight.

A 16 year old game that still hasn't lost it's charm as it continues to give me and countless others amazing experiences. I would recommend that anyone who wants to play a team-oriented FPS choose this wonderful masterpiece of a title. It's one of the best games of all time and in spite of the odds, it still lives with a flourishing community of dedicated players that are always eager to welcome newcomers!

I've loved this game forever, but due to day-to-day software requiring a newer version of MacOS because they are no longer supported by anything below Monterey, I've been forced to update my system to Monterey, and as a result I can no longer play this game. Playing it via bootcamp is also no longer an option, and as much as I love this game, I don't see there being another way to play it. I'm not buying a new computer just to play it either. If anyone from valve ever sees this or anything similar to this review- please consider trying to update the game so that is can run on MacOS Monterey and above, since stupid Apple decided to drop support for 32-bit applications. Please also consider updating it to run on ARM processors. This has been a favorite game of mine, as well as so many others, and I know the OSX playerbase is negligible, but still...

Welcome to Team Fortress 2. After nine years in development, hopefully it will have been worth the wait. To listen to a commentary node, put your crosshair over the floating commentary symbol and press your primary fire. To stop a commentary node, put your crosshair over the rotating node and press your primary fire again. Some commentary nodes may take control of the game in order to show something to you. In these cases, simply press your primary fire again to stop the commentary. In addition, your secondary fire will cycle you through all the commentary nodes in the level. Please let me know what you think after you have had a chance to play. I can be reached at gaben@valvesoftware.com, and my favorite class is the Spy. Thanks, and have fun!

While I do not recommend this game‚Ä¶ That does not change the fact it is something that I do still enjoy and will continue to enjoy. It scratches the itch of being able to work on a mechanic of gameplay and continue to master it over time with a new and old set of players all the time. It‚Äôs formula of team based shooter is pretty much a perfectly imperfect masterpiece and very well did set the standard going forward which I might argue was for the better or worse depending on what a new games spin on it happened to be. Back to the game itself so the skill ceiling is very punishing if you aren‚Äôt in an environment that you even get a chance to improve. A lot of that can come down to tolerance of how people act online and your own personal drive to put in time either looking for content relating to the game or literally working on game mechanics in MGE or the such. I do not blame people for not wanting to deal with a lot of the players you will run into with this game but at the end of the day you hold your own principles. We are online and you should expect things to play out as they can being online.

This game has had a lot of ups and downs since I first picked it up in Orange Box on the PS3. Three of the biggest issues being Bots, Hackers and generally the game being on life support. However, despite this the game still persevered as a result of a loyal playerbase, venerable content creators and a few select individuals who refuse to let it die on the Developer end. To all of you who fall in any of those three categories? I thank you.

As of recently bots have become significantly less of a problem and I haven't come across a single hacker in the past 30 hours I've payed as of this review. The game absolutely needs a free update as it's primary source of new maps is paid content (cheap or expensive as $0.99 a map for community made content that doesn't need to be modded in and therefore can function without forcing everyone to download a mod pack). That said, I still love this game and while it would be amazing. The game is in a surprisingly good stat for how long it's been since the last official update.

MvM (Mann vs. Machine) is still a very fun PVE circuit you can do casually for free or Mann Up for a tour of four to six maps that drop rare loot for each one you complete with extra gains for completing the tour. Community Servers have all kinds of wild fun things like unique game modes, custom maps and more, Casual is a collection of all of the official maps and game modes (and possibly some officially recognized community content) and Competitive is a much more slimmed down experience with some of the more irking features like Team Auto-Balance and Random Crits removed in a neat and tidy 6v6 game. If you're looking for a fun PVE/PVP Co-op FPS that's literally free for everything except the weapon skins, hats and taunts? I'd say give it a shot if you haven't already and if you have and are questioning my sanity? Try again. With no bots and very few trolls, the game has made as much of a comeback as it can without another major update releasing new content.

Beautiful and enjoyable game. Goofy but the community provides casual and competitive scenes granting lots of  variety. The game's official casual mode is great and you can play 12v12 games with many different maps and game modes. Competitive gamemodes (made by the community) grant mostly control point based,  6v6  matches that follow a certain meta game. Other modes like highlander grant 9v9 games with each player on a different class. Overall the game is suitable to all types of gamers. Be it sweating your pants of or just having a laugh with mates. This game is the game for you!

Frankly speaking, this game has become stale. Not because of the lack of updates or lack of any major changes. That adds onto it, but god is the community so annoyingly toxic. In my many years of life I've never met bigger crybabies and bigots who just whine about everything. They die? They must say a slur. They die to a critical hit? They say another slur. Just feels really tiring having to deal with such people on a pretty much hourly basis. Quite literally a similar thing is happening with the bots. Back in the day, or rather quite a bit after the Jungle Inferno update (the last major update that brought actual content other than maps) bots started to slowly appear and the community started to simply find other ways to try to enjoy the game. It got to such a point that we literally had to ask Valve to fix the game only for them to partially fix the issue, but then nothing else. F2P players still cannot communicate with the outside world, bots still appear every 10th, 50th, 100th game and they still peak in numbers on certain maps every so often. 

The game could be better meta-and-balancing-wise, but that does not matter if I cannot literally enjoy it for the reasons mentioned above. It's such an amazing game with even more potential, but seals will not save anything if Valve does not do anything about everything. Hopefully it won't be a 'too little, too late' case. Maybe not everything has to be a drastic decision, but if the bots get completely patched, I'll be at least partially satisfied.

But seeing that the next 1-2 years will mostly be spent working on CS2, a game that is already garnering a lot of complains, then yeah... 

I'll just say that we want changes and we should demand them. Even if it's an update the size of the Summer update every 6-24 months and it includes MEANINGFUL changes, then maybe we will see TF2 flourish once again.

Oh and if people are just willing to say "grow some balls" then consider the following: how about you grow some balls and don't act like you're on a high horse when you literally live like a Discord moderator. It's just painful to see this game being neglected and yet half of the community still doesn't recognize that fact for some reason.

this game is legendary and a showcase to a time period that is no more. the golden age of gaming where social media was scarce and the internet wasn't mainstream. this game among others not only set standards that we currently see within all forms of video games, but was among the few means of meeting others in the then popularizing period of the internet, of which few were initiated into a culture that's now obscure by today's internet zeitgeist.

team fortress 2 is basically the video game form of msn messenger. this game was the deal back then, and it would be hard to describe what it was like to experience it when it was fresh and new, and not taken for granted. you were in the internet click when you played this game. it was a new frontier for anyone who's never been introduced to the internet. it's a basic game by today's standards, but the community is still here after more than a decade. there a few games that will stand the test of time like this one, and for these reasons this is why i recommend you play team fortress 2.

I've played this game since 2007, and nearly every other even semi-popular game since Doom was released, and it's the greatest game I've ever played.
Team Fortress 2 is a catalyst for absolute chaos, insanity, hilarity, frustration and probably a good half of the memes on the internet. This is what I'd consider one of the last AAA bastions of absolute freedom in the FPS genre.
What do I mean by "absolute freedom"? Well, it's a source-engine game, and valve likes to share, so the entire community gets tools to basically do whatever they want. 24/7 server that only plays one map for weeks? You got it. Mario Kart? You got it. Randomizer servers? You got it. Chill-out servers where everyone just dances and screams memes on the microphone? You got it, mister!
It's also old enough to shake off most of its issues. Competitive works. Pubs work. There are hardly any bugs that didn't become features of the engine itself and there's tons of strange places to end up just browsing the community tab.

So come play TF2, the best game ever made and I hope you find out why it is.

Team Fortress 2 is hands down one of the best games out there. It's been around since 2007 and has millions of players visited with its fast-paced action, strategy, and humour. The game's characters are a huge part of what makes it so awesome. They all have their unique backstories, personalities, and abilities. With nine different classes to choose from, you're always finding new ways to play. The gameplay is insanely addictive. It's fast, but not so fast that you can't keep up. The team-based gameplay is also super satisfying. Each class has a specific role, so you always feel like you're contributing to your team. Whether you're defending a control point or pushing the payload, it's always an exciting experience. But it's not just the gameplay that's amazing. The Team Fortress 2 community is also amazing. There are so many fans out there who have created their maps, mods, and short films based on the game. The art style is colourful and unique, and each map has its look and feel. The humour in the game is another big draw. The dialogue is witty and the taunts are ridiculously funny.  All in all, Team Fortress 2 is a masterpiece. It's got addictive gameplay, memorable characters, and a unique sense of humour. Whether you're a long-time fan or new to the game, you should definitely give it a try.

This could still be a fun game after all these years (I purchased/received in 2007 it looks like), but the community has turned it into an absolute cesspool. It seems nothing can be about the rampant cheating, wild bots spamming non-sense (audio AND text chat), and absolute onslaught of in-game buffoonery. Games either become aimbot fests where a few cheaters go around one-shotting every other player or dance/taunt expositions in a public area with no real purpose.

The game needs to die or the anti-cheat technology needs to catch the hell up.

I'm also not a fan of the sheer number of micro transactions. If you want some of the best weapons, you have to either get insanely lucky, grind ad nausea, or pull out a credit card to buy/trade for them. These add-on purchases of costumes, taunts, and assorted stupid shit only adds to the aforementioned buffoonery most servers devolve into.

I currently have ~1500 hours in OW, between 1 & 2. Mainly in Comp

When OW2 was announced, I was prepared to pay $60 for the entire PvE portion of the game. Since then I have spent $0 on OW2.

I believe that these are the reason I feel cheated as a OW1 player:
The first edition of the game cost $40/$60, that version of the game was made offline, thus our game we paid for was taken from us
We have been dying for changes and content since 2018, but were told to wait under the guise of Overwatch 2
After that we got the same Christmas, Halloween, and Summer games events every year, we were told that major new events and updates would be toned down as the PvE content was coming along
Issues with OW1 reached a boiling point (CC in every new character, ability, moth meta, GOATS, hero bans, role queue etc.)
We were told this all would be resolved in the new Overwatch, where everything could happen, and nothing was off the table
Jeff went on stage and promised us everything we could want

On release disappointments:
New heroes were locked on release, as this is now a FTP game, which was very opposite from OW1 (But not from the industry)
5v5 was kinda baked, but some hero interactions really did not work
Free BP was essentially content-less, thus OW1 players that did not pay got NOTHING (Except Kiriko?)
Store prices were/are very high, not that I am against selling cosmetics, but they are crazy
PvE very much absent
Map pool that rotated, which made the game feel empty of content
2CP removed (no replacement)
Cards removed
On fire removed
Endorsement system gutted
Looking for group removed
OW1 competitive history removed
Level/Portrait border removed

On release positive changes:
A roadmap of hero releases, which included 3 new supports, and two tanks, we needed this
Three new heroes
Great cinematics as usual
Great UI and ping system changes
A new gamemode with maps to back it up
Increase in fidelity, while keeping performance great

I do think Overwatch is a good game, I mean all of us would not be playing if it was just boring or bad. I want to rate this poorly as I think that there are major issues with the development of Overwatch since 2018, but regardless this is still a game worth playing, so it is recommended.

This has to be one of the most fun games to play and even though it is so old already, the graphics still look good to this day and it is still enjoyable to play from time to time. It only lacks with the amount of updates it used to have and that would make the game more alive. It also lacks having a working anti-cheat system and a block system for bots, because you can literally see them in almost every match. It could have more contracts and seasonal events with new maps as well, not just new cosmetics.

But overall it is a very good game and it deserves every attention it has, only if developers saw more effort to it.

I absolutely adore this game as it's one of my favorite games of all time, however there's an overwhelming feeling of a blatant lack-of-care when it comes to the game.

I've looked through the source code when it was leaked and I can see that there's an overwhelming amount of things wrong with the game (such as pyro flamethrower range being assigned to particle effects, unneeded references for Merasmus in character classes, etc.) that create a lot of bloat and a lot of spaghetti code by developers who have created many aspects of the game in a roundabout way.

Unfortunately, Valve doesn't care enough about this game to even go back and make heavy patches or fixes. The game, as it stands, is a broken mess that has been almost completely abandoned by its developers. Which is terrible for the community, considering we regard Team Fortress 2 as one of the best first-person shooters of all time.

When the pandemic happened there was an influx of bots on the game, and I remember people complaining about it and defending Valve in forums saying that the pandemic is crunching the development of the game, so it could be explained that they would patch it out and fix it. The only problem is that the pandemic is no longer at a point of international concern, and the devs still haven't fixed any of the reoccurring issues.

The only updates that have been made are mostly related to cosmetics and fixing the appearance of those cosmetics. The maps still has issues of terrible map geometry and other issues that should've been fixed a long time ago, but Valve has taken a step into only caring about the cosmetics and whatever will make them the most amount of money.

I love Team Fortress 2, and I also love Valve as a company, but it's from decisions like this where it feels as if the community for this game isn't being listened to that make people stop supporting Steam and head to other places to purchase their games. Team Fortress 2 is a fantastic game, but I'll never be able to recommend it in its current state of pure broken chaos as it continues to have been abandoned by its community.

The last major TF2 update was in 2017, and as of writing it is now 2023. I was in elementary school when it had released, and now I am about to graduate high school taking college courses with no major updates or any changes until the 2023 summer event with Saxton Hale. This does not suffice as there's still a (now moderate) bot issue with casual servers, and no updates for the Steam Deck's compatibility like Half-Life 2, Portal 1 & 2, and Left 4 Dead 2 got. 

It is absolutely painful to be in a neglectful relationship, because you know that no matter how much to cry and pray to be listened to you never will be. You can only take so much before you fully abandon and move on within your life, and unfortunately since Valve refuses to listen to this game's community I'm going to just move on. There's a lot of memories and fun from my childhood that spawned because of TF2, and unfortunately the lack of being listened to was the straw that broke the camel's back. I am just going to move on from TF2 since there's a lot of other forms of entertainment I could invest myself into anyways, hopefully more fun and maybe some that'll provide even more meaning for me.

Over the years, the things that I‚Äôve appreciated about Team Fortress 2 have changed a lot as I‚Äôve matured. When I discovered the game at eleven, the thing that hooked me was the colorful cast of characters and the unique artstyle. Through my teenage years, it was the wacky and deeply unserious community that gave me a sense of belonging. Though I‚Äôve become frustrated and jaded with the TF2 community over the years, even as an adult, I developed a newfound appreciation for the raw mechanical skill ceiling and beautiful complexity of high level Team Fortress 2. Even if this game never gets another update again, there‚Äôs always something that will bring me back to the greatest class based shooter ever created.

Adolf Hitler, byname Der F√ºhrer (German: ‚ÄúThe Leader‚Äù), (born April 20, 1889, Braunau am Inn, Austria‚Äîdied April 30, 1945, Berlin, Germany), leader of the Nazi Party (from 1920/21) and chancellor (Kanzler) and F√ºhrer of Germany (1933‚Äì45). He was chancellor from January 30, 1933, and, after President Paul von Hindenburg‚Äôs death, assumed the twin titles of F√ºhrer and chancellor (August 2, 1934).

Hitler‚Äôs father, Alois (born 1837), was illegitimate. For a time he bore his mother‚Äôs name, Schicklgruber, but by 1876 he had established his family claim to the surname Hitler. Adolf never used any other surname.

Early life
After his father‚Äôs retirement from the state customs service, Adolf Hitler spent most of his childhood in Linz, the capital of Upper Austria. It remained his favourite city throughout his life, and he expressed his wish to be buried there. Alois Hitler died in 1903 but left an adequate pension and savings to support his wife and children. Although Hitler feared and disliked his father, he was a devoted son to his mother, who died after much suffering in 1907. With a mixed record as a student, Hitler never advanced beyond a secondary education. After leaving school, he visited Vienna, then returned to Linz, where he dreamed of becoming an artist. Later, he used the small allowance he continued to draw to maintain himself in Vienna. He wished to study art, for which he had some faculties, but he twice failed to secure entry to the Academy of Fine Arts. For some years he lived a lonely and isolated life, earning a precarious livelihood by painting postcards and advertisements and drifting from one municipal hostel to another. Hitler already showed traits that characterized his later life: loneliness and secretiveness, a bohemian mode of everyday existence, and hatred of cosmopolitanism and of the multinational character of Vienna.

In 1913 Hitler moved to Munich. Screened for Austrian military service in February 1914, he was classified as unfit because of inadequate physical vigour; but when World War I broke out, he petitioned Bavarian King Louis III to be allowed to serve, and one day after submitting that request, he was notified that he would be permitted to join the 16th Bavarian Reserve Infantry Regiment. After some eight weeks of training, Hitler was deployed in October 1914 to Belgium, where he participated in the First Battle of Ypres. He served throughout the war, was wounded in October 1916, and was gassed two years later near Ypres. He was hospitalized when the conflict ended. During the war, he was continuously in the front line as a headquarters runner; his bravery in action was rewarded with the Iron Cross, Second Class, in December 1914, and the Iron Cross, First Class (a rare decoration for a corporal), in August 1918. He greeted the war with enthusiasm, as a great relief from the frustration and aimlessness of civilian life. He found discipline and comradeship satisfying and was confirmed in his belief in the heroic virtues of war.

Still the greatest free to play game of 2007 but still part of the problem. Love the game, I hate the lootboxes.  Short and simple. Games like Counter-Strike: Global Offensive and Team Fortress 2 fuel peoples gambling addictions and show their profits. To Valve's benefit however they have a robust marketplace where you almost never have to gamble unless you really want some specific 1000$ cosmetic.

I didn't know about the hundreds of trading sites when I made this review, but once I got premium, I had as many hats as I could shove down my fat throat. Surprisingly, the hats were this game's undoing for me. There was a nitpick that made the game damn near unplayable, and it was literally being unable to see my cosmetics on my character in first person. I bought the Cute Suit for the Engineer like three years ago, and the game slowly became unplayable because I couldn't see his gloved hands in first person. Same with the Arsonist Apparatus for the Pyro. After a while, the nitpick bothered me to a point where I just stopped playing. Especially not being able to see Halloween cosmetics unless it's Halloween or full moon. And yeah, you're right, I could just play on community servers. But I get tired of hoping onto x10, Minecraft, trading servers after a while. I'm trying to get back into the game because it was one of my favorite shooters but it is weird that small nitpick turned me away from one of the greatest shooters in gaming history.

I have my own gripe but let's get the necessary bit out of the way: 
Valve has effectively abandoned this game. Not too long ago, the casual mode was literally unplayable for over a year, though that has gotten significantly better. Still, many weapons are unbalanced, and this game is extremely unforgiving to beginners. 
The game has taunts and cosmetics that make up a large section of this game and its community, but you have no hope of getting any of them without paying up besides a couple achievement cosmetics. You also need to find, trade, get achievements for, or craft weapons to get any but the first loadout of each class. So, as though first playing this game to begin with isn't already incredibly difficult because this game completely fails to actually teach you how to play, as well as inherently being difficult for new players just by the nature of the actual gameplay, now you also have to unlock flexibility. Beginners are literally handicapped because they can't switch their loadouts for situations.
And now to my gripe: You know how I said there are just a few achievement cosmetics that pretty much are the only cosmetics you can get, save for the cosmetic find maybe once every 6 months? If you accidentally delete them, they're gone. You can't get them back. If you reset your achievements to get the achievement for that cosmetic again, it just doesn't work. If you contact steam support, they have a "No returning deleted items under any circumstances" policy. Achievement items are not tradeable. And the way you get these achievement cosmetics is through the find system. Once you gain the achievement, you "find" the achievement cosmetic. This also means that when you get them, if you're not careful, you might delete them. I got this game when I was fairly young and thus didn't know what I was doing, so I deleted every item I found, including the achievement cosmetics. My account is completely unable to get these cosmetics forever.

Fellow Team Fortress 2 players, I accidentally deleted my achievement cosmetics the second I found them a LONG time ago when I was too young to know what I was doing. In particular, I can never get back the Ghostly Gibus. And Valve has completely abandoned their game, save for their second spare janitor to help the first one when they half-*ssedly said "We hear you!" after they got shouted at to support their widely loved game. They will never fix this issue. I'm livid. Still gonna play it, though.

INGREDIENTS for Easy Croissant recipe :
Flour :400 gms
Milk:260 ml
Butter:180-200 gms
Sugar 4 Tbsp/60 gms
Salt :1/4 Tsp
Active Dry Yeast:1 Tsp
For egg wash:Beat 1 egg+1 tsp milk
METHOD
We can make this easy croissants in three simple steps.

1.Prepare the pastry sheet
2.Proof them
3.Bake them.
Let me show you the three steps in detail.


Step 1.PREPARE THE PASTRY SHEET
To make the croissant pastry sheet,we need to prepare the pastry dough.

(1)Prepare the dough
Easy croissant recipe
Activate the dry yeast by dissolving 260 ml warm milk ,4 Tbsp sugar 

Easy croissant recipe
and 1 tsp active dry yeast.

Easy croissant recipe
Add 1/4 Tsp Salt into 400 gms of flour.

Blend together the wet and the dry ingredients in a large bowl.

Easy croissant recipe
Easy croissant recipe
until we get a homogenous evenly hydrated dough.

(2)First Proofing
Easy croissant recipe
Let the dough sit and rise for 1 1/2 to 2 hours or until the dough get doubled in size.

Easy croissant recipe
Degas the dough and divide the dough into 12 equal pieces.

Roll each piece of dough into the shape of a disc which is approximately 16-18 cm in diameter and not more than 2 mm in thickness.

(3)Layer butter on each disc.
Easy croissant recipe
Place the disc on a plastic film and repeat the same process for the next piece and stack them over the previous disc and continue the same with rest of the divided dough pieces.

Easy croissant recipe
As butter is very soft now, we need to freeze them for 30- 35 minutes;so that the butter will not be very soft and will be pliable and it will be easy for us to work with the dough.

Easy croissant recipe
Roll them into long rectangular sheet.

Easy croissant recipe
With the help of a knife or a pizza cutter,cut them into smaller triangles.

Shape them into croissants

I love my baking tray .. non stick,highly durable, easy to clean,made of high quality carbon steel and coated with enamel .

Step 2.PROOF THE SHAPED CROISSANTS for 2 hours or until they puff up a little.
butter croissant recipe
STEP 3.BAKE THE CROISSANTS
Give another egg wash and Bake it at 400 F for 10 minutes and then reduce the temperature to 375 F and bake for another 8-12 minutes.

After baking we will get a beautifully caramelized golden brown,flakey,buttery,delicious croissants.

 Now you can make bakery type croissants in a very easy method and get rid of those preservatives and trans-fat that are used in store bought ones.

Watch the video to see how easy it is to make FRESH HOMEMADE CROISSANTS using this easy croissant recipe.

How long do croissants last?
The precise answer to that question depends to a large extent on storage conditions ‚Äì keep freshly baked croissants in a dry area.

How to store croissants
Store croissants at Room Temperature
This Homemade Easy croissants stay fresh at room temperature for about two days. Keep them from both drying out and absorbing moisture from the air by storing them in a plastic bag or wrapping them in foil.

If you want to bring exterior back to crispy,heat the rolls directly on an oven rack at 200 degrees Fahrenheit, but leave them in for only 2 to 3 minutes so they don‚Äôt get overly browned.

Short-Term Storage
You extend their shelf life to five to seven days,when you store the croissants in the refrigerator. Wrap the rolls in the same way you would for storage at room temperature, in plastic or foil.

Croissants return to room temperature after about one hour out of the refrigerator. If you want to speed up the process, place the cold rolls directly in a warm oven for 3 minutes to heat them and restore their crispness.

Long-Term Storage
Can you freeze croissants?
Yes,Frozen croissants are safe to eat after freezing for one year, but they stay fresher if you use them within two months.

Shelf life of Unbaked Frozen Croissant pastry sheets is upto three months.

How to freeze croissants?
Wrap croissants tightly with aluminum foil or plastic freezer wrap, or place in heavy-duty freezer bag.

Double-wrap the rolls tightly, first with plastic and then with foil. If you plan to cook unbaked croissants within a week, you can also freeze them directly on a baking sheet and place them directly into the oven without thawing.

Baked croissants reheat well in the oven when they are still frozen; give them a few more minutes than you would heating thawed croissants.

How long do croissants last in the freezer?
Properly stored, they will maintain best quality for about 1 to 2 months, but will remain safe beyond that time.

How to know if croissants are bad or spoiled?
The best way is to smell and look at the croissants: discard any that have an off smell or appearance; if mold appears, discard the croissants.

I started TF2 in 2008 on the Xbox 360. I was one of the best. Playing the same handful of maps over and over. As update after update came on the PC, I refused to switch over except for a little achievement farming and item collecting. I read the comics, bought the merch, dressed up as the Gentlemann of Leisure. I listened to Control Point, a Team Fortress 2 Podcast. Team Fotress 2 had an enormous impact on me as a kid. 

In college, I moved over to PC in time for the Robot Boogaloo update and became a Pupstomper, getting 36 kills in a single life as a Heavy on Payload. I got a few thousand kills with strange weapons, crafted a few hats, and then called it quits. After playing almost every week for 8 years, I stopped in mid 2016. 

Since then, every few months I've thought about selling my TF2 backpack, but I couldn't bring myself to do it. When Jungle Inferno came out, I was left behind. In the past 6 years, TF2 has changed a lot and now I'm not a kid anymore. I'm nearing 30; TF2 and I have grown apart and even with the Summer Update, I don't think we can ever have the relationship we once had. I tried to recapture that old excitement, but the spark is gone. 

Reinstalling TF2, that's not the hard part. It's letting go.

Team Fortress 2 is a great game that pretty much everyone is familiar with by now. But for those of us who have yet to explore the game‚Äôs level of online play or tournament scene, it may not be immediately clear where to start. To make finding your way through the game easier, here are seven tips to help you score in each class and take your first steps in playing competitively.

Sniper

Sniper is probably the most readily available class for new players, and arguably the one which has the easiest setup. There‚Äôs no in-depth class progression or item builds to learn. All you have to do is pick up a mouse and a keyboard, find some friends, and then begin building up your skills. Being able to shoot fast and shoot accurately with little to no movement and relying on gunpowder and a sniper scope are some of the most compelling reasons to play sniper.

Related: Best PC Games

To that end, make sure that you keep an eye on your surroundings. Check for safe areas to hide and shots to take, even when you‚Äôre in a highly populated area. Some maps have walls which you can climb on or hang from, or tree trunks to hide behind, so even if you‚Äôre pinned down you can still survive a few shots.

Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, gamers of all ages, gather 'round as I regale you with a tale of absolute mayhem and mirth in the wild world of Team Fortress 2! Get ready to embark on a journey that's like strapping a rocket launcher to a unicycle ‚Äì it's fast, it's furious, and it's funnier than a clown juggling flaming rubber chickens.

Picture this: a game where the objective is as clear as mud on a rainy day, and the characters are more over-the-top than a Shakespearean play directed by a caffeinated squirrel. From the moment you enter the battlefield, you're thrown into a colorful chaos that makes the circus look like a Sunday picnic. You've got the Heavy, a mountain of muscle with a minigun that could double as a leaf blower. Then there's the Spy, who can disguise as the enemy and backstab them with the elegance of a well-dressed ninja ballerina. And who could forget the Pyro, a fire-loving maniac dressed in a hazmat suit ‚Äì because flames and fashion are a match made in... well, not heaven.

But let's talk about the weapons, shall we? It's like the game designers raided a toy store and thought, "What if we had a rocket launcher that shoots actual words?" And thus, the "Quizzical Quasar Quantum Queller" was born! From bats that turn your enemies into statues to guns that heal your teammates by serenading them with love songs, TF2's arsenal is a masterclass in the art of weaponized absurdity.

The maps are a whole other level of bonkers. Whether you're defending a control point shaped like a hamburger or escorting a cart through a carnival-themed battleground, you'll never know what kind of madcap adventure awaits around the corner. It's like Disneyland for trigger-happy thrill-seekers.

But the real magic of TF2 lies in its community. In a world where toxicity can spread faster than gossip in a soap opera, Team Fortress 2 stands as a shining beacon of camaraderie and camaraderie-induced hilarity. You'll find Engineers constructing intricate contraptions, Medics offering free healthcare (with a side of ubercharge), and Scouts zooming around like caffeinated squirrels (coincidence? I think not).

So, my pixelated pioneers, if you're in the mood for a game that's as unpredictable as a cat on a pogo stick, as uproarious as a stand-up comedy show on a rollercoaster, then Team Fortress 2 is your ticket to a world of wacky warfare. Get ready to embrace the chaos, savor the shenanigans, and shoot your way into a universe where laughter is the ultimate weapon. Remember, in Team Fortress 2, victory might be sweet, but the real treasure is the bellyaches from laughing that you'll earn along the way!

Its very hard to give this game a negative review, but the state of this game for the past 3 years has been unacceptable. This game has not got a real content update since October of 2017. The only thing that has been added since is the worst cosmetics in the game that do not fit the art style and some good maps here and there. 
The game is extremely unoptimized and requires you to download a script to fix it which is crazy for a game from 2007. Without external optimizations, i struggle to run this game at a consistent 165 FPS. Every single other comparable game i can run with hundreds of frames and no frame pacing issues, not this one. this doesn't even touch the amount of bugs that are game breaking at times. weapons like the man melter are unusable due to horrible visual glitches. 
Even with all of these issues I would still recommend this game but one thing in particular has ruined it outright. The bot issue has been going on for years at this point and valve has done very little to do anything about it. They have made the game worse for free to play players and have done nothing to fix the issue. the game is completely unplayable at times. Right before writing this review, I got on to play a few matches. The first one had a blatant hacker that no one wanted to ban and the next 2 were ruined by bots! How is this game still alive with players or being sold, completely broken! They constantly add extremely overpriced stuff to the shop as well. Taunts are selling for 8 dollars at times.
 I love this game, but it is in the worst shape ever right now and until the billion dollar company that owns it actually does something fixes it, i cant recommend this game. BTW a lot of people that like this game will act like nothing is wrong and the bot problem is minor. It isn't. They are very jaded and delusional from supporting a broken product for years now. This game needs some serious help for years now and it hasn't got any of it.

Pros:
Free 2 play (But has limitations for the F2P version that aren't nearly as bad as other games, and payment for entry is literally 5 dollars)
Every Class is available and ready to learn
Weapon drops that offer alternative styles to play the classes you already enjoy
High skill ceiling
Mostly friendly community
Plenty of game modes and servers to jump into, with a brand-new community gamemode just recently added.
PVE Content (granted there is payment for entry if you want the drops that come from it)

Cons:
Free 2 Plays have no access to use Voice Chat, Text Chat, or In-game voice commands. (Due to some bad apples spoiling the fun) Their inventories are also much smaller than the average Paid Player.
Game has a medium-high skill floor, while not impossible to play, you more often than not will find yourself getting stomped on the first few weeks.
Game currently has a bot problem, while not nearly as bad as it used to be it can certainly ruin the experience for first time players.
Lack-luster tutorial, (would still recommend it if you're completely new to FPS games, but would also recommend looking tutorials up online.)

Summary:
While TF2 isn't exactly the most friendly to newer players, the community as well as learning the games mechanics more than make up for this initial flaw. TF2 isn't a perfect game by any stretch but there is a reason why so many people clock in a lot of hours into this game, myself included. If you're an OW2 refugee, someone who just saw a funny TF2 meme on the internet, or someone who just wanted to see what all the fuss was about, I would honestly recommend giving this game a college try. If you ultimately play as a friendly or try your heart out, I welcome you to the wonderful world of Team Fortress 2. 

Personal Rating: 9.5/10
Non-Biased Rating: 8.5/10

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning. I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

I started playing TF2 in 2013, when I was only 10. I am now 20 years old, and would like to reflect on my time wasted on this steaming pile of garbage. 

- Valve has basically abandoned this game for its more mainstream (and more competitive) games, CS:GO and Dota 2. It gets nowhere near the average playercount of these two, and has never been anywhere near it. The last actual update that wasn't just more cosmetics for stupid whales to collect was the Jungle Inferno update, which came out almost 6 years ago.

- The economy is effectively dead due to the above reason, and everything is insanely inflated. Person-to-Person trading was also nearly killed off with the creation of trading bots, who watch the market for the slightest margins and create buy/sell listings to kill off any actual competition. 

- Cheating is rampant, due to VAC being possibly the worst anticheat out there. Cheaters are usually loser children who have nothing better to do than sit on their computer and totally own! actual players, with there being some exceptions for those at the top. The most notorious cheaters are usually the most deviant freaks you will find on planet earth, proudly displaying how gross and weird they are. 

- There are bots running 24/7 from the same group of people who join public lobbies and try to take them over. These people unironically dedicate their time and system memory to running bots in a game that is basically dead. 

- The competitive scene is dead. It's all community hosted tourneys.

I hold this game very near and dear to me for various reasons. I've played for over 10 years on and off ever since I was a little dude on the Xbox. I've met some really cool people thanks to this game and have a lot of good memories. I'm still making new memories to this day either through playing with friends or from strangers in the community. It's not a perfect game, of course, but it's one I have to thank a lot for making me who I am today. It would be impossible for me to list all the reasons I love and continue to enjoy this game in one single review without writing an entire novel, but it's the addicting gameplay, fun characters and many communities throughout various community servers over the years that have kept me here for as long as I have. Many of my informative years were spent on Trade, Deathrun, VSH and CTF community servers, and nowadays I spend a lot of my time in Casual and on various servers like Uncletopia and Skial. TF2 was my social hub for many years and even though now, Discord is usually to go-to for most people to hang out, TF2 for me still manages to creep it's way into all kinds of places. I don't think I'll stop playing anytime soon, and I hope this game continues to thrive despite circumstances. I love Team Fortress 2.

This game is actively collapsing in on itself and no "look at the new high player count!" is going to fix that. Bots are still a problem, blatant cheating (usually being stacks of cheaters in casual who can votekick whoever they want), and there is a very clear lack of desire to do anything with the game on Valve's part.

I've played this game on and off for a decade and no matter how many times people say "it's good again!" it feels like it's in a worse and worse state every time I return. Every added map is some garbage baby's first map that was made five+ years ago, official VSH feels like a waste of resources that could've been spent on actual game improvement.

Until Valve adds some basic security measures like they've done with other titles such as CS:GO, I cannot recommend anyone try TF2 for the first time or return to it unless they have an active friend group to play it with.

As an avid gamer, I've had the pleasure of experiencing countless titles over the years, but few have left a lasting impression quite like Team Fortress 2. Even after all this time, this game stands tall as a true masterpiece, with its brilliant blend of engaging gameplay, charismatic characters, and a dedicated community that keeps the flame burning bright.

Team Fortress 2's core gameplay is nothing short of exhilarating. The distinct classes offer unique abilities and playstyles, creating a balanced and endlessly entertaining experience. Whether you prefer to unleash havoc as the explosive-demolishing Demoman, provide vital support as the Medic, or lay down suppressive fire as the Heavy, every class has its own distinct role, making teamwork and strategy an absolute must. This dynamic and diverse gameplay ensures that no two matches are ever the same, keeping players engaged for countless hours.

One of the game's most significant strengths lies in its whimsical art style and quirky characters. The vibrant visuals and cartoonish aesthetics not only age remarkably well but also add a sense of lightheartedness that sets Team Fortress 2 apart from the grittier shooters out there. The characters themselves are brimming with personality, each with their own distinct voice lines and humorous interactions that inject an infectious sense of fun into every moment of gameplay.

Beyond the game's engaging mechanics and visuals, Team Fortress 2 boasts an incredibly devoted community. The dedication of its players is a testament to the game's longevity. From the passionate modding community to the frequent updates and events, Valve's ongoing support has kept the game fresh and exciting, even years after its initial release.

Moreover, Team Fortress 2's community-driven nature has given rise to countless fan creations, from artwork and animations to hilarious memes and unforgettable videos. The camaraderie and camaraderie among players transcend the game itself, creating a sense of belonging and friendship that extends beyond the virtual battlefield.

As a long-standing title in the gaming world, Team Fortress 2 has earned its status as a timeless classic. The game's unparalleled gameplay, charming art style, and devoted community make it an absolute joy to play, whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer eager to experience its wonders. Team Fortress 2 is more than just a game; it's an experience that leaves an indelible mark on the hearts of all who venture into its zany universe.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that seamlessly combines exhilarating gameplay, memorable characters, and a strong sense of community, look no further than Team Fortress 2. This masterpiece deserves all the praise it receives, and it will undoubtedly continue to be a beloved title for years to come.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

    [*]Some of the maps, while trying their best, feel one sided or just in general not the best for gameplay or fun, but these are made by players like you or me, so can't get mad for people making content for free, for a nearly 20 year old game that even the developers don't want to touch with a stick...
[/list]

Once upon a time, in a world far less ordinary and much more eccentric, there existed a game of such splendiferous wonder, it made one's head spin faster than a top in a whirlwind. This magnificent spectacle goes by the name of "Team Fortress 2".

Imagine, if you will, a land of bright colors and oddball characters, where one minute you're engaging in a heated gunfight, and the next you're prancing about wearing an absurdly oversized hat. Such is the delightful absurdity that pervades every pixel of Team Fortress 2.

Now, this isn't just any run-of-the-mill game. Oh no, it boasts of nine peculiar characters, each brimming with quirks and talents, like nine colorful candies, each with a unique flavor. The Scout zips around with an energy of a sugar-buzzed bumblebee, the Heavy, much like an elephant with a temper, creates havoc, while the Spy, sly and slippery as a fox, sneaks behind enemy lines. Each character is a tale in itself, narrating a saga of laughter and warfare.

The battlegrounds of Team Fortress 2 are as varied as Wonka's own confectionery concoctions. One moment you find yourself amidst the dust and heat of a desert outpost, and the next, you are thrust into the freezing snow of an icy wasteland. Every map is a new adventure, each mode a fresh twist in this candy-cane story.

And then, my friend, come the hats. Oh, the extraordinary, the spectacular hats! More in number than the candies in Wonka‚Äôs factory and stranger than his Oompa-Loompas. From towering stacks to flaming headgear, collecting these hats could very well become an adventure of its own.

In the grand scheme of games, Team Fortress 2 stands out like a golden ticket in a sea of ordinary chocolate bars. It‚Äôs a barrel of laughs, a tub of excitement, and an ocean of wacky fun. So, if you're ready for a dash of thrill with a pinch of silliness, step right up and welcome to the whimsical world of Team Fortress 2.

How to cook corn:
Boiling

Remove the husks and silks from the corn.
Bring a large pot of water to a boil.
Add the corn to the boiling water and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the kernels are tender and bright yellow.
Drain the corn and serve immediately.
Grilling

Remove the husks and silks from the corn, but leave the husks on.
Brush the corn with melted butter or oil.
Grill the corn over medium heat for 10-12 minutes, or until the kernels are tender and slightly charred.
Serve immediately.
Here are some additional tips for cooking corn:

Use fresh corn whenever possible.
If you are boiling corn, make sure the water is boiling before adding the corn. This will help the corn cook evenly.
If you are grilling corn, do not overcrowd the grill. This will prevent the corn from cooking evenly.
Serve corn immediately after cooking. This will help to keep the corn moist and flavorful.

Instead of posting a joke review, I'll be upfront and honest with my opinion.

As a person who plays Spy, Medic, and Demoknight, Team Fortress 2 has given me countless experiences that no other game could offer me. I have good things to say, and personal criticisms.


I will say the good things first, and that mainly starts off with my long-time main Spy.
Spy is a class that takes hard work and perseverance to learn, but the more you practice and journey with him, the more you'll be rewarded.

You may start off dying a lot because you ran into mistakes an amateur would make, and then get frustrated after the Sniper, Soldier or Engineer taunts at you, but that's what they are; mistakes. Learning from them is the only thing you can do, and the more you learn what to avoid doing (and/or reading guides), the better you will get, and it is hugely rewarding; as you can start gaslighting the enemy and making them paranoid of you. Once they start obsessing with you, don't take your deaths personally; your team is going to destroy them with your help.

Spy as a class is unique to this game and I haven't seen another multiplayer game where I've felt so good destroying someone who was distracted.


Other good things include picking loadouts, which give you vastly different items for vastly different play styles. Demoman can be either your average Demoman with the grenade launcher, stickybomb launcher, and (get this) the bottle, or you can have the Demoknight who uses a sword, shield, and boots. I don't think many first person shooters let you go from Rainbow Six Siege to Fire Emblem.

Though that's all I can really say about the goods. There's probably more I can think of, but I don't want to keep this review too long.

As for one of my major criticisms, I can't help but feel the "counter items" were completely unnecessary in this game. The biggest offender being the Sniper's shields, Razorback and Darwin's Danger Shield.

Razorback's only use is to counter Spy, and DDS's only use is to counter Pyro. Stun-on-backstab, and afterburn immunity (probably to counter the Flare Guns). The mitigation for Razorback? Use your gun. The mitigation for DDS? Any other class. No, seriously.

Homewrecker would be a nice addition if it weren't for the fact one of its abilities literally is something only the Engineer should be able to do. Knocking off a sapper in one swing? Really? Using the afterburn to cripple the Spy isn't enough?

Regardless, those three are the main problems I have in terms of item balancing.

As for any other issues... well, I'm not gonna join the parade on bitching about Random Crits; but other issues I had were match-by-match, and not with the game itself.

Honestly, I still play it to this day due to how unique it is, but.. To be honest, the only way to really know how good this game is, is to play it yourself.

I won't even play this game anymore, the game's dead to me in my eyes, in the eyes of once a gullible child. I watched it die under life support, just like my grandfather who I've never really got to know yet he still made me cry that he's been leaving from us from this world. Maybe I wasn't around during his last days of life yet I still really miss him dearly. This is also a kind of allusion this game gave me. There's something parallel between these events as the most enjoyment I had in Team Fortress 2, I also had way back with my grandfather. I vaguely remember these days but I respect him as he was the remniscent and the last grandpa who stayed alive for so long. While I wasn't that commited before I saw him but once I did, I was the saddest kid living on the world. Nowadays my two grandmas hate on each other and they won't even let us in, due to [i]family business[/i]... let us just give my grandfather a moment of silence he deserves and remember him for who he was, not what we saw him be like during last days as I grew up I started to realize that he was the only hope there.....

Well, the minute has passed, let me continue my review as this was just the beginning and the introduction to what the review will be like. I think I've expressed myself enough there for you to understand what we're dealing with.

Anyway, I've kept hearing many, many promises from Valve and they don't just care anymore and I feel like they broke the deal after all. The first red flag which I saw immediately was the rebranding of this update from [i]update-sized update[/i] to [i]holiday-sized update[/i]. My concerns just grew further, still recovering from the Crate Depression of 2019 as to in what ways they were capable of ruining this game's estabilishment it grew during its [i]golden years[/i]. I still remember the day the Mecha Update was introduced and the new gamemode was amazing, it was very refreshing and brought the way of playing the game that wasn't thought of before, this is very in Valve fashion to make and provide interesting solutions to their games which have been tested and proved to live up to expectations. Too bad these words don't live up to today's Valve standards and I think the development course the TF2 takes is self-destructing and degradive for the hardcore TF2 fans which I am such fan myself included. I still can not believe that people honestly support this Hat Pressure dropping off the Valves from the Source itself. They think they can keep getting away with it, cutting the budget constantly only to underdeliver to their most beloved fans to return the Bitter Taste of Defeat and Lime. They can't admit they lost the battle with cheaters as this would mean the complete abundance of TF2 from community side. Don't worry, of course they care, just not in the way you would think.

[i]Look, there's that new VSH mode in the map pool! Go and play it now! You're gonna love it![/i] Yes, something refreshing, something new, I've been waiting for this for many years, oh yes, new voicelines, new maps, new cosmetics, new balance changes, new stuff-stuff-stuff! [i]From this time we'll be always delivering to you the updates you wanted for so long! Look ahead and stay tuned for the Winter Update 2023, it's going to be something special![/i]. Yes-yes-yes! [i]I can not believe that I managed to steal this much content and still not be seen as a filthy thief who just happened to know what the community has been scraping for the most.[/i] Uh-oh, this is not good, let's see what's wrong about it all, shall we?

Dumbass, of course, all of the new voicelines were made cheaply by the new voice actor with vocal range fitting the most TF2 mercenaries, nothing wrong, yeah? New voicelines! We don't mind that Valve could just try at least contact JB Blanc to record lines for Saxton Hale himself? We don't mind that people have been waiting for this update many, many years just to see it being underwhelming, just like TF2 always lately has been? Okay, do we still mind that dead people like Rick May should have at least got some respect paid here and not get replaced by a cheap knockoff from the 7-Eleven? Just like the hard work the community did with so many other things that never seen the light of TF2's day, working from 7-11 just to see their workshop submissions get ignored by Valve entirely in place of other items? At least when they take something from the Steam Workshop, they should do it right, not take it and make it as theirs. I mean, they have resources to deliver us the voice actors together and they just seem to be not commited entirely at all into cooperation with the community.

Alright, new maps, welp, I think I kind of seen them all before, next.

New cosmetics, ho-ho-ho! This is a tradition at this point. Since hats got introduced, it remained steady to introduce hats for loads of years. I mean, they're not boring like they usually have been but come on, this isn't going to fix the bot problem, Valvey, do something about this first, hats should be the least of concerns.

Cool, this update also saw some balance changes and it includes a map that has been unchanged, like it has been engraved into a stone and it stayed that way for years. When I saw that cp_steel has changed, I was honestly shocked. This means that there has been a complete disregard to the original vision of the map, just to make the annoyed people by this map smile just a tiny bit.

Look, I don't want to break it to you but Team Fortress 2 is literally a dying brand, a shadow of its former self. They aren't going to make it any better anymore, they're soon gonna dump it into trash and I think that by the year 2027, like it's 20 years for this game to even exist so for it to then die after it's [i]years of service[/i], serving its most commited traders and economists and preventing them from getting bankrupt. Team Fortress 2 is just like one of these games that have been ever made, it happened and now it's going to die. Death is unevitable.

As much as I loved this game from the beginning, I am now aggresively positioned against it as I watch it decompose into something unrecognizable and I mean it starts to mutate now, like a fricken corpse. Go on with your lives, it's time to accept that Team Fortress 2, the once game of our beloved childhoods, is coming to an end and this won't change.

For all of the people who have been supporting this game with greatest of the honors being Rick May and also my grandfather who has been passively watching over my life, it's time to sunset this game for good. I am leaving this game entirely, I am selling my entire lifetime spent in TF2 and I am never going to come back to it. My patience for this game is over. Goodbye, everyone. Stay safe out there, y'all deserve a rest. Dismissed.

Overall, TF2 is a solid game. It's well balanced, action packed, and has a pretty dedicated community behind it. I truly think this game has found a formula that will let it live forever.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

It really is a timeless classic. As long as there are servers open, there will be people playing. Now until forever.

Team Fortress 2 is a free-to-play first-person shooter. I have played this game for about three to four years now, and I still enjoy countless hours in it. It was the first game I played alongside Terraria and Garry‚Äôs mod. What makes it unique is that the conflict is presented in a comical style. There are still many players found playing Team Fortress 2 right now. 

As you play you can unlock more items or weapons which you can use in your fight. You can also of course trade with others for loot; just make sure they‚Äôre trustworthy. There is an aspect of play for everyone in this game. There are different classes for each play style such as support, defense, and attack. In total, there are nine different classes that you can choose from including classes like sniper, scout, and medic. 

Even though you may not be good you first initially start and pick up the game, as you play and spend more hours in-game your skills and technique will improve. Once you get a class mastered you will find fun and enjoyment in this game. The majority of the players in-game or on your team do not really care if you are good or not and that is another aspect of Team Fortress 2. There are also many servers to play on and there are even practice/tutorial servers to help you improve your skills, or master a class to play. 

Team Fortress 2 also has many game modes such as capture the flag and Control points. There are also other games like pass time. As you play the game you will be able to find a game mode that you enjoy the most. Along with the abundance of game modes, there are also a lot of maps to experience with different environmental settings. 

In the end, I would say that this is a really good game to install and play when you have time because there is not much more like it for free. As you play the game you will grow to a higher level. This game also has a numerous amount of achievements for those achievement hunters. Whether you are a skilled individual or a beginner this game has opportunities for everyone to experience.
