It exceeded my expectations when I started playing this game for the first time yesterday.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

[A bell rings out in alarm. The Administrator's voice comes over the speakers as a large sign board lights up.]

Administrator: "Intruder alert! A RED Spy is in the base!"

[Camera pans down to show a BLU Soldier reading the sign board.]

Soldier: "A RED Spy is in the base?"

[Soldier grabs his shotgun off a gun rack and runs down the stairs.]

Soldier: "Hut hut hut hut hut."

Administrator: "Protect the briefcase!"

Soldier: "We need to protect the briefcase!"

Scout: "Yo, a little help here?"

[Camera moves to BLU Scout pulling on a door handle. Soldier pushes him out of the way and enters numbers into the keypad.]

Soldier: "Alright, alright, I got it. Stand back son. One, one, one, uhh, one!"

Scout: "Let's go, let's go, let's go!"

[A BLU Heavy runs towards them and the door from behind.]

Heavy: "Incoming!"

[Heavy runs into the Scout and Soldier, breaking down the door with Sasha, his minigun. Heavy runs towards the briefcase, knocking Scout and Soldier over in the process. Scout crawls up from the floor, while Heavy lowers his gun.]

Scout: [Screams,]... "Hey, it's still here."

Heavy: [Yells,]... "Alright then."

[Camera pans to behind Heavy. There is a BLU Spy holding a BLU Sniper over his shoulder. The Sniper is dead.]

Spy: "Ahem, gentlemen."

["Meet the Spy" text appears.]

[Spy adjusts the corpse of Sniper and walks towards the briefcase.]

Spy: "I see the briefcase is safe."

Soldier: "Safe and sound!"

Scout: "Yeah, it is!"

[Scout and Soldier stand up.]

Spy: "Tell me, did anyone happen to kill a RED Spy on the way here?"

[Scout shrugs, Heavy and Soldier look at each other and then back to Spy.]

Spy: "No? Then we still have a problem."

[Spy tosses Sniper's corpse onto the desk, showing the Sniper still has a Spies knife in his back. A sharp musical cue plays.]

Soldier: "And a knife!"

Scout: "Ooh, big problem. I kill plenty of Spies. They're dime-a-dozen back-stabbin' scumbags. Like you! Ow. No offence."

[Scout takes the butterfly knife out of Sniper's back, spinning it around before cutting his finger and dropping the knife. He puts the cut in his mouth.]

Spy: "If you manage to kill them, I assure you, they will not like me."

[Spy spins the knife much better than Scout, fancily closing it and handing it to Scout, who takes his cut out of his mouth.]

Spy: "I am nothing, nothing, like the man loose inside this building."

Scout: "What are you? President of his fan club?"

[Soldier laughs behind Scout. Spy walks over to the windows next to the desk.]

Spy: "No.."

[Spy turns back to Scout.]

Spy: "That would be your mother!"

[Spy brings out a Manila folder. He slams it against the desk, and it has "TOP SECRET, SCOUT'S MOM" written on it. Multiple images of the RED Spy and BLU Scout's mother being intimate fly out of the folder and onto the desk. The camera shows us close ups of three of the images.]

Scout: [Stutters in shock.]

[Scout, Soldier and Heavy all look at the photos. Scout with confusion and anger, Soldier with interest and Heavy mostly uncaring, but a little shocked.]

Spy: "Indeed, and now he is here to f**k us! So listen up, boy, or pornography starring your mother will be the second worst thing that happens to you today."

[Spy grabs a cigarette from his case, Scout looks like he is ready to attack Spy, Heavy and Soldier are trading the images of Scout's Ma.]

Soldier: "Oh!"

Scout: "G-gimme that!"

[Scout begins to collect the images, taking them from Heavy and Soldier. Spy takes a drag from his cigarette and looks out the window at a map of the world.]

Spy: "The Spy has already breached our defenses..."

[The camera changes to show the RED Spy running along a hallway. He hides behind a rock quickly, before tossing a Sapper at a BLU Sentry, destroying it, and shooting the Engineer.]

Engineer: "Sentry down!"

[The Engineer falls through a door, dead, and the RED Spy shoots something off camera.]

[Cut back to the three BLU's in the intel room.]

Spy: "You've seen what he's done to our colleagues!"

[The camera pans down to the deceased BLU Sniper before fading into this Snipers fight with the RED Spy. The Spy raises his knife, ready to backstab, but the Sniper hears him and defends himself with his rifle. The Spy kicks him into a wall, where Sniper grabs his Kukri, attempting to attack the Spy. The Spy dodges, but gets a slash on the Snipers left cheek. Sniper goes in for the attack, but Spy gets the best of him, backstabbing the Sniper. His body falls through the wall onto the ground below. Fight sounds are heard throughout the scene.]

[Cut back to the three BLU's.]

Spy: "And worst of all, he could be any one of us."

[Cut to the RED Spy fighting a BLU Medic. Spy gets a hold on him and disguises himself as the Medic. The disguised Spy hits the Medic, causing his glasses to fly into the air, and for the real Medic to fall to the ground, assumed dead. The Spy grabs Medic's glasses mid-air and puts them on.]

[Cut back to the three BLU's.]

Spy: "He could be in this very room! He could be you. He could be me! He could even be-"

[Spy looks at the camera, but is cut off by his head being blown off. Soldier reloads his shotgun after shooting his teammate. Scout and Heavy look on in surprise. The images and the folder Scout was holding flies into the air.]

Scout: "Woah, woah, woah!"

Heavy: "Oh..."

Soldier: "What? It was obvious! He was the RED Spy! Watch, he'll turn red any second now."

[The camera shows Spy's foot, and Soldier nudges it with his shotgun.]

Soldier: "Aaaany second now..."

[The camera changes to show Heavy and Soldier, who are crouching next to the Spy's body. They do not notice when the BLU Scout changes his demeanor to be much more unaffected by the murder of his teammate. The Scout looks around the room, to make sure no one is watching.]

Soldier: "See! Red! Oh wait, that's blood..."

[The camera changes again, to be following the BLU Scout as he un-flicks the knife, slowly approaching the unsuspecting BLU's.]

Heavy: "So... We still got problem."

Soldier: "Big problem..."

[Scout approaches them, knife ready.]

Soldier: "Alright, whos ready to go find this Spy?"

[The Soldier and Heavy are unaware as the BLU Scout uncloaks and turns out to be the RED Spy. The Spy lifts his knife, prepared to backstab both of them.]

RED Spy: "Right behind you."

[Both Heavy and Soldier gasp and turn to see the Spy.]

[Team Fortress 2 ending flourish music plays. The sounds of the Soldier and Heavy being murdered can be heard during this.]

Team Fortress 2 is one of the best games of all time, easily. Valve knocked it out of the park the way that they're known for, and the game has received numerous updates that have improved the game over the years.

However, in the current day Team Fortress 2's main mode, the online matchmaking mode known as "Casual Mode" has been almost completely overrun with bots who play as The Sniper class and cheat to kill players from any distance instantly. These bots make about 70%~90% of Valve's casual servers unplayable at most times of the year and most times of the day. An abandoned game overrun by bots is one thing, but the Valve corporation continues to add microtransactions to the game to this day and massively profits off of this game through that and the exchange of in-game items through the Steam Market. I feel that it is immoral the sheer amount of money that Valve makes off of Team Fortress 2 while doing nothing about the bots ruining it's most popular mode on Valve's own servers.

I love Team Fortress 2, but I cannot in good faith recommenced it to anyone as long as Valve continues to do nothing about the bots in casual mode. I really hate to see such a beloved game left to rot.

I hit 1000 Hours over a year ago, and even got a job (No Longer have that job) as an Administrator for a TF2 Community, And it was all thanks to my love for this game. 
I wont ever leave TF2, Its where I got friends, Had fun, Got a job, And this game saved me from suicide. I was so lonely in April 2020 when I stumbled across this game, I was ready to kill myself. 
One click on this game, And I was in heaven.
Thanks to this game I became a slightly popular Twitch Streamer, Had about 300 Followers on Social Media (Banned due to false accusations and drama.), And am now Elite Grade on my Casual Badge.
This game will be with me for the rest of my life, And If I die, Ill make sure I left TF2 Running.
While I have taken on more healthy hobbies (I'm a railfan and transit enthusiast nowadays.), I still enjoy playing a round of Team Fortress whenever I have the time.

TF2 is a great game, and the inspiration for all those hero shooters out there. I recommend every hero shooter player to at least try it for a few hours, as it can be an amazing experience.

Pros
- It's a timeless classic
- All the classes are balanced very well (except maybe for the Spy)
- Very skill based
- Top 10 on the Steam active players leaderboard (so there's a lot of people playing it)
- Very creative and welcoming community

Cons
- Lack of support from developers (last major update was 6 years ago!!)
- Steep learning curve
- Casual queue games are sometimes filled with aimbot sniper bots, but this never happens in Community Servers

If you haven't played this game before, then there's no reason to start playing now. I personally started playing for a few reasons, but my experience so far is average at best.

1. Game has many cheaters/bug users. One-shots at full health (not sniper). Kills through floor with rockets, without taking damage and so on. I've seen VAC owners playing on VAC protected servers...
2. The game has many AFK players.
3. The game has no ping filter when you join "Casual mode" (despite the fact that wiki said that matchmaking should put you in a nearby located server). You can see ping 100+ often.
4. The game has many dumbasses and degenerates. Idiots that vote to kick you for no reason or as revenge. Idiots that don't try to bring the case back, and just troll teammates.
5. The game has many people who waste time writing dumb, childish messages. 
6. The game has many players that just want to dance whatever, instead of killing the enemy. It's "funny" once in a while, but not as often as it happens in TF2.
7. People trash talk in chat sometimes. Sometimes I feel like I'm in a class for mentally challenged kids.
8. The game has MANY furries and transformers. 
9. The micro-economy in TF2 is one of the worst I saw in games. Valve style. Loot boxes that require expensive keys to open and now weapon skins of different qualities...
10. Spy class.
11. I played on 2Fort in 70% of my matches. 10% was popular map with cart. The rest 20% was on different maps.
12. Trolls.
13. Menus/mode UI is bad. Server browser is outdated (hello 90s). Main menu has poor design. 

It reminded me of a quote from one movie. 

‚ÄúI See You Alone, Surrounded By Enemies, And It Breaks My Heart.‚Äù

I'm not saying that this applies to all players, but I think that bigger half of players are either A) Transformers, B) Have a questionable financial history (to say it politely), C) Have weak hardware, so they can't play more modern games (TF is a 2007 game), or combination of these. I mean you can have fun, sometimes, in certain scenarios... If you like cartoonish/Pixar graphics, very casual matchmaking and TF humor. The problem is that it's often not "fun" because of reasons above. If you plan to rent/host a server, use some balance mods (like class limit), set a connection filter and punish cheaters/trash talkers/degenerates, then the game will be fine. For a guy that just wants to play on a random server, it's not a lot of fun. To my deep disappointment (no, really), there is no known alternative to TF2. By alternative, I mean hero shooter with cartoonish graphics. Different classes, different modes. A game that you play to have fun, while still ACTUALLY TRYING TO KILL YOUR ENEMIES, without cheating/bugs etc. Overwatch 2 can be fun, but it has problems too. I'm not saying that making games is an easy job, but games like this one are a lot easier to make, than the one with huge detailed map, lots of cutscenes etc. A good in-game economy can bring a lot of money. Today we have an unintentional monopoly in the face of TF2. 
I hope that I made it clear why I play (possibly will still play...for some time) this game. 

To potential players - Avoid this game. Let it die. It's an old game with too many problems. The more I played it, the more problems I have found. It's not just bad as competitive game (I don't care), but also as casual game.

Valve please fix your game.

     Pyro (CQC centered class) can use the scorch shot to flame you from across the map.
And not even aim is technically required to do that, since it's a splash damage based weapon.
Plus the afterburn does insane damage, please fix it.

     Sniper's exploitable skill ceiling and his balance issues (razorback, dds, quickscoping) makes him stupidly
powerful in comparison to the other 8 classes in this game, since it's a hassle to put a long-ranged focused
class in a game where literally everything excels at close-mid range. And as the years go by, people get better, and games get unplayable.

       Random crits are just unfun to play against, because of how its rampup works.
The more damage you deal..  well, equals the more damage you deal! Also, random bullet spray is not equally as bad but it's quite a little bit of a problem when it does affect gameplay.

       And Spy.. i know the class has been nerfed into oblivion already but please fix the ping problems associated with hitreg and hitboxes, and i think that's all of my complaints on TF2.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

6 tablespoons unsalted butter

1/2 cup white sugar

1/2 cup brown sugar

1/4 cup water

1/4 teaspoon cinnamon

1 pinch salt

5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced

1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.

Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.

Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Team Fortress 2, developed by Valve Corporation and released in 2007, is a game that initially garnered attention and praise for its unique art style and promise of exciting team-based gameplay. However, as time has passed, it has become apparent that the game falls short in several areas, ultimately leading to a disappointing experience for players.

One of the main issues with Team Fortress 2 is its lack of meaningful updates and support from the developers. Despite its initial popularity, the game has been plagued by a lack of new content and a slow response to fixing bugs and balancing issues. This lack of attention from the developers has resulted in a stagnant gameplay experience, with little incentive for long-term engagement.

Furthermore, the game's balance is a major concern. While the concept of different classes with unique abilities and roles is appealing, the execution is flawed. Some classes are vastly overpowered, leading to frustrating and unbalanced matches. This lack of balance not only hampers the enjoyment of the game but also discourages fair competition and strategic gameplay.

Another major drawback of Team Fortress 2 is the prevalence of hackers and cheaters. The game's lack of effective anti-cheat measures has allowed cheating to run rampant, resulting in an unfair and frustrating experience for legitimate players. This undermines the integrity of the game and drives away dedicated players who seek a fair and competitive environment.

Additionally, the game's overall performance and optimization have not aged well. Despite being over a decade old, Team Fortress 2 often suffers from technical issues, including crashes, lag, and poor server performance. These technical shortcomings detract from the gameplay experience and hinder the enjoyment of the game.

Lastly, the community itself can be toxic and unwelcoming. While every online game has its share of negative elements, Team Fortress 2 seems to have an elevated level of toxicity, with instances of harassment, bullying, and disrespectful behavior. This toxic environment can make it difficult for new players to feel comfortable and enjoy the game.

In conclusion, Team Fortress 2 fails to live up to its initial promise and falls short in several key areas. The lack of updates and developer support, imbalanced gameplay, prevalence of cheaters, technical issues, and toxic community all contribute to a disappointing experience. While the game may have had its shining moments in the past, it struggles to remain relevant and fails to provide a satisfying and enjoyable team-based shooter experience in its current state.

Game doesn't feel rewarding to play. Every time I have logged into this game, I have logged off angrier and sweater than when I started. If you want to put yourself in a bad mood, just pick any public server and play a couple rounds.

 I WANT to like this game, I want to look at the scoreboard and see my name at the top. I want to win. I want a good K/D ratio, I want to feel like I supported my team, and to feel satisfied after a match. But I don't and I never will. I have over 660 hours in the game and I regularly lose. I get mad. I blame my team mates. I rage. I mald in chat. I change my class, and I still get killed. I get dominated by at least two players per match. in 660 hours and I should have learned SOMETHING but I still just barely outskill a fresh F2P. 

I'm not going to get good at this game, no matter how many more hours I put into this game. I'm just going to keep on losing and dying and getting mad and being salty. Instead of doing that, I'm going to uninstall the game, and try to not play it anymore. There is this small amount of naivety buried deep inside me that says if I just play for a little while longer, I'll get better, but that same voice said that same thing 100 hours ago.

If you want a challenging, teamwork based First Person Shooter, and you can tolerate losing, then this game is perfect for you. If you're akin to me, and want to play games you're skilled at, please, pick something else.

Throughout all the bots, whining toxic players and lacklustre updates I've met plenty of chill people and you guys are a huge reason to why I keep enjoying this game so to those people thank you for making the experience for me (and probably others) much more enjoyable.

I think TF2 is the gold standard of hero-based shooters, evident by the fact that almost everything after it seems to try, and fail, at making itself a "TF2 Killer". One minute you could be fighting and killing like any standard multiplayer experience, the next you can be in a 60 man conga line across the map. Which is why it's sad that the biggest threat to the game's existence are a bunch of friendless middleschoolers who froth at the sight of a good game beating all their "flavor of the month" battle royales at longevity and basic fun. And since people with the ability to doxx and pipebomb these little shits are too pussy to do it, then we'll have to wait for the devs to fix it. I'm not switching to another game or playing on the soulless, tryhard infested community servers

TF2 is the best game I've ever played ever since Totally Accurate Battle Simulator and Goat Sim. TF2 is the game I play on Sundays when I'm feeling down and have a good time playing with other people when there isn't a horde of bots. First we have the recognizable characters the one that comes out of my mind first is the Heavy, the first class to be shown in the "Meet the Team" videos which are lore driven and comedy filled adventure with about 20 minutes of Meet the Team videos, my favorite is going to Meet the Spy not because I'm a Spy main I will say it I am a Huntsman main which are very rare I just find his mechanics to be very fun especially the hanging ragdoll corpses because this is the best game engine ever which is in Garry's Mod and it is Source! Second we have the cosmetics, because this game is free it is bound to have paid items, mainly are weapons, war paints, and weapons and much much more that I can't list, I know this is unnecessary but my steam accounts most expensive cosmetic is in Steam Market value would go to the Nuts and Bolts Wraith Wrap and in Market value so Marketplace . tf is the Medimedes which is very cool but again the prices for something like a golden frying pan is as much as your rent which makes me pissed to say at the least. The third thing is that the gameplay overall is good and well balanced if all the players are playing stock but playing with different weapons could make it unfair and a balancing nightmare for example the Rescue Ranger is a essential item for defensive engineer because the engineer can heal is buildings far away and it cost approximately close to a full one dollar in cash oh no I meant Steam Funds not real cash and speaking of which the in-game store "The Mann-Co Store" is dog water the prices of these cosmetics and weapons may sound like they're expensive but I've bought items in marketplace . tf and their prices are approximately 5 to 10 cents while something like the Desert Marauder for Sniper is 11 dollars while in marketplace it is 10 cents, very big difference between the Mann-co store and Marketplace . tf and weapons are even worse some weapons like the Righteous Bison first of all complete trash is about $1.30 or $2.00 which is a steal the items actual value is about 3 cents, very much a scam not in deception though. The last thing I want to talk about is the downsides I'm not listing every downside because I would be here for hours typing, first we have that there's a constant swarm of hacking bots which headshot across the border and kills all the people in the opposite of them and they try to kick innocent players out of the game which is downright terrible I doubt that there would be a fix for these bots because Valve would have to take down the cheating software so LmaoBox which is a big icon Valve took down CS:GO lottery websites basically gambling your money for stupid skins which are just textures on a weapon while Valve hasn't done a single thing to LmaoBox, they literately make you pay to have a bot which is not VAC (Valve Anti-Cheat) detectable while the free one is VAC detectable. This is just horrible. Then a pretty niece topic is the ingame non cheating bots, the practice bots first of all the training for this game is horrible and doesn't even teach you the basics of Soldier everybody's main right now, it doesn't teach you about rocket-jumping, a essential aspect of Soldier for his slow mobility, so to say it they are limited with the maps you can do, first can't even play a underrated map, Hydro try to create a nav-mesh for the bots they don't even move at all the only gamemodes they can do is attack and defend which is only Dustbowl and Gorge which is abysmal, King of the Hill which doesn't even have my favorite King of the Hill map which is Harvest, and Payload and they don't even have support for my favorite map for payload which is Frontier so I have to generate a nav-mesh for the bots to navigate even then it isn't perfect and they can't by default do Capture the Flag so you have to generate a nav-mesh for them and they're AI is absolute garbage in their default maps all I can say is that they're vanilla AI is garbage. But there is a much better improvement to these bots like with Left 4 Dead and like that game you can use mods to improve their AI I highly recommend Bot-Overhaul by Showin it is amazing, because of this mod I play with bots all the time, first they have support for much much more maps and even gamemodes like the previously mentioned Capture the Flag and they have different weapons instead of stock weapons also they come with cosmetics that's how I get my ideas for cosmetics to get on the marketplace outside of the TF2 Wiki but I can say that sometimes they do get stuck on Badwaters second BLU spawn and it is mostly unfixable while the only positive I'll give to the vanilla bots is that they don't get stuck much in other maps I'll also say that Bot-Overhaul doesn't get much updates usually they are bug fixes but even then it doesn't persuade me from downloading the mod I'll also say that the installation process for the mod is complex for the first time but the more you get used to it the better you get also they have a tutorial for how to install the mod so if you don't now how to install the mod then look up for example on YouTube "How to download Bot-Overhaul in TF2" you also get results from the creator Showin who gives a good guide of how to install the mod but a another con I have is that it tanks performance don't have the maximum amount of bots for me I make it a 6v6 so it's fair and doesn't hurt my FPS as much this FPS problem is because the game is spawning bots with different weapons that aren't stock that can already tank performance but the worst of all for lower end computers like mine is that it spawns bots with cosmetics, already in Bot-Overhaul and TF2 in all there is 100's of cosmetics and already having about 31 bots with different weapons and cosmetics each time can tank performance. But this is the end for my long review about Team Fortress 2 but overall I would rate it a 8/10 for really good gameplay when playing stock but is full of bots so I would recommend to go on community servers which isn't infested with hacker bots I mainly play in Achievement Engineer servers from LA but this is the end of my review and bye.

Soldier: "A RED Spy is in the base!?"

[Intruder Alert begins to play. The Soldier reaches from off-screen and pulls a Shotgun off a rack of weapons. Cut to the Soldier dashing down the stairs and through the 2Fort sublevel while saying "Hut, Hut, Hut!" with every step he takes]

The Administrator: "Protect the briefcase!"

Soldier: "We need to protect the briefcase!"

[Camera pans to reveal the BLU Scout trying to open the code-locked 'Briefcase Room' door]

Scout: "Yo, a lil' help here!?"

[The Soldier pushes the Scout aside and begins to 'decode' the combination]

Soldier: "All right, all right, I got it. Stand back son. 1, 1, 1, umm... 1!"

Scout: Let's go, let's go-

[BLU Heavy comes around the corner, Sasha in hand, charging towards the Scout and Soldier]

Heavy: "INCOMING!"

[Heavy shoulder-barges the door, destroying it. The three of them are sent tumbling and screaming into the Intelligence Room. The Scout reaches the desk to discover the briefcase is perfectly safe]

Scout: [while screaming, he notices the briefcase] "AAAAAHHHH- Hey, it's still here!"

Heavy: "-AAAAalright then."

Spy: "Ahem."

[Camera zooms in to reveal the BLU Spy, with the BLU Sniper's corpse over one shoulder]

Spy: "Gentlemen."

[Meet the Spy' Title Card]

[Cut back to the Spy, carrying the dead Sniper towards the desk]

Spy: "I see the briefcase is safe."

Soldier: "Safe and sound, mm-hmm."

Scout: "Yeah, it is!"

Spy: "Tell me... did anyone happen to kill a RED Spy on the way here?"

[The other three BLUs shake their heads and shrug]

Spy: "No? Then we still have a problem."

[He deposits the Sniper's body on the desk, revealing a bloody Knife in his back]

Soldier: "...and a knife."

[The Scout approaches and removes the knife]

Scout: "Oooh, big problem. I've killed plenty of Spies; they're dime-a-dozen back-stabbing scumbags - like you!"

[The Scout attempts to manipulate the knife like the Spy, only to cut himself on the finger and drop it]

Scout: "Ow! No offense."

Spy: "If you managed to kill them, I assure you, they were not like me." [The Spy deftly retrieves the knife and flicks it shut, handing it back to the Scout] "And nothing... nothing like the man loose inside this building."

Scout: "What're you? President of his fan club?"

[The Soldier and Heavy chuckle]

[The Spy turns to face the Scout]

Spy: "No... that would be your mother!"

[The Spy reveals a folder and slaps it down on the table, revealing several compromising photographs of the RED Spy and the Scout's mother]

Scout: [stammers out of shock and disbelief]

Spy: "Indeed, and now he's here to f**k us! So listen up boy, or pornography starring your mother will be the second worst thing that happens to you today."

[[[Right Behind You]] plays]

[The Soldier and Heavy examine the photographs. The Heavy leans over and shows the Soldier one photo in particular]

Soldier: "Oh!"

[The Scout frantically retrieves the photos as the Spy lights and smokes a cigarillo in the foreground]

Scout: "Gimme that!"

Spy: "This Spy has already breached our defenses..."

[Fade to the RED Spy, creeping through the Hydro tunnels. He pauses at a corner, as the camera pulls back to reveal a BLU Level 3 Sentry Gun with its Engineer. He slides an Sapper across the floor, disarming and destroying the Sentry Gun immediately]

Engineer: "Sentry Down!"

[The BLU Engineer throws his Wrench down and frantically reaches for his Pistol, only to have the Spy shoot him in the head with the Revolver. The dead Engineer crashes through a door and the Spy steps over him and fires at a target off-screen]

[Cut back to the BLU Intelligence Room. The BLU Spy leans over the dead Sniper, gesturing frantically.]

Spy: "You've seen what he's done to our colleagues!"

[Flashback to the BLU Sniper, now alive and sniping from a dusty attic. The RED Spy creeps up on him and steps on a creaking floorboard, alerting the Sniper, who engages the Spy with the Kukri. A struggle ensues, and the Sniper is ultimately backstabbed]

[Cut back to BLU Intelligence Room]

Spy: "And worst of all, he could be any one of us..."

[Fade to the RED Spy fighting a BLU Medic, armed with a Bonesaw]

Medic: "Raus, raus!"

[The Spy breaks the Medic's arm, disarming him. Close-up on the Spy's face as he disguises as the Medic, sans spectacles]

Medic: [gasps] "Nein..."

[The Spy kills the Medic with a well-placed chop to the throat, knocking off his spectacles, which he catches and wears, completing his disguise]

[Cut back to BLU Intel Room. The BLU Spy looks frantic]

Spy: "He could be in this very room! He could be you! He could be me! He could even be-"

[The Spy is cut off as his head explodes violently. The camera switches to the Soldier, Shotgun in hand, with a confused Heavy and a panicked Scout]

Scout: "Whoa, whoa, whoa!"

Heavy: "Oh!"

Soldier: "What? It was obvious!" [The Soldier pumps his Shotgun, discarding the spent shell.] "He's the RED Spy! Watch, he'll turn red any second now..."

[The Soldier and Heavy approach the dead Spy, with The Soldier prodding the Spy's foot with his Shotgun]

Soldier: "Any second now... See? Red! Oh, wait... that's blood."

[The Scout lingers behind, his expression sinister. He approaches the Soldier and Heavy, retrieving the knife he pocketed earlier, and flicking it open easily. As he approaches, he flickers and melts, revealing himself to be the RED Spy]

Heavy: "So, we still got problem..."

Soldier: "Big problem... all right, who's ready to go find this Spy?"

Spy: "Right behind you."

[Team Fortress 2 ending flourish music plays, with the stabbing of the Soldier and Heavy punctuating the beat of the tune.]

[Petite Chou-Fleur plays]

[Fade to the scattered photos of the Scout's mother. The RED Spy retrieves one of them and smiles wistfully]

Spy: "Ahh... ma petite chou-fleur."

[The RED Spy walks off with the BLU team's intel in tow]

A classic. Even without updates, TF2 still remains to be as fun as it has always been with its multitude amount of balance and variety with its weapons and classes.

The game isn't as dead as most people make it out to be. TF2's community is very self-sustaining, and most cheaters and bots are oftentimes kicked immediately by the community.

Despite that, bots sadly are still a problem and can really ruin your enjoyment depending on the server you joined, and some people don't even bother kicking them at all. Nonetheless, I still think it's worth giving this game a try despite the lack of updates

The original Overwatch, better in almost every way and more deserving of your time.

It's the Smash Melee of team based FPS.  Super fun and casual if you want, but with incredible depth that the most skilled players can shine.

Sure Overwatch does the competitive scene better, because their game is designed around it and that's all it is.  Valve really did drop the ball in the regard and could use a better built in ranking system / competitive scene support. (Just like nintendo ironically)

But that's all OW has, sometimes you just want to jump in and have some fun instead of getting screamed at on voicecomms by some 13 year old because you picked McCree.  Where's the fun 20vs20 servers you can just jump in and mess around in?

You may not understand it if you've never played this before, but this is probably the greatest game ever made. If you've played this for at least decent while, you know exactly what I'm talking about. Other contenders for the title of GOAT simply lack something this game has in spades, such as infinite replayability, a strong playerbase that is still hitting over 100k players daily even almost 16 years after release, and no other game has a class as fun and as unique as Spy. The fun you'll have and friends you'll make are all part of what makes this game so genuinely amazing. I love this game like an old friend; one I may not have seen for years on end at times, but I can still come back and to talk to them for hours on end like not a day has gone by since we last spoke, and treasure every single moment I spend with them.  I spent at least half of my hours of playtime running the game on a piece of crap laptop that got maybe 23 FPS on all lowest settings while using the lowest resolution available, as that's how dedicated I am to this game. I may not know what true love is when it comes to people, but damn it, I sure as hell know what it's like to truly love a game unconditionally with every individual fibre of my being. If or when this game dies, I will cry infinitely more for this game than I will at my own father's funeral. I fucking love you, Team Fortress 2. You may be #2 in name, but you'll always be #1 in my heart. Truly the best to ever do it.

This game is amazing. It's a steam must-have. The gameplay is intense but calm at the same time. Some matches are fair and balanced, but on rare occasion there is one where you crush the enemy or they crush you. The Mann Co. store and the Community market are chock full of items you can buy. There is great diversity of characters, from the fast and squishy Scout with his scattergun, to the tanky Heavy with his minigun. 
This game is highly recommended, and is constantly updated almost every other week, keeping the game as bug-free as possible.

Note from 2023: There has not been a major update in nearly 2,000 days. Still really fun though

Team Fortress 2 can feel unbalanced at times, with certain classes or weapons being overpowered or underpowered compared to others. This can lead to frustration for players who feel that their preferred playstyle is not viable or that they are at a disadvantage in certain situations.

Additionally, the game's graphics and visuals may feel outdated, as the game was released over a decade ago and has not undergone significant updates in this regard.

Finally, the game's community is toxic and unwelcoming, which can detract from the overall enjoyment of the game.

In 2011 when TF2 went F2P, there was an influx of cheaters. But they were not as common as rabbits. VAC bans and community servers with active moderation made TF2 a fun experience that you could recommend. 

A few years later, Valve begins to neglect the game. Mann Vs Machine is probably the last really good update for the game. The matchmaking update made the UI just... atrocious to navigate. Despite criticism, the community server browser is just packed away and hidden in a corner still. The community server browser is still the same code that Half-Life 1 MP uses. 

The source code for TF2 gets leaked. Some talented people see this as an opportunity to time machine TF2 back to where it used to be. A time before the balance changes and cosmetics that pollute the original vision of silhouettes always being recognizable. Some choose to extensively mod TF2 into a new vision, unrestricted by what current TF2 mod creators are limited by. There's even a project to port TF2 to Source 2. Unfortunately, law is absolute and does not distinguish intent very well. Those projects were temporarily shut down while lawyers had to figure out how to allow creative people freedom, but not give the same rights to someone with worse intent. Unfortunately the damage was done and most of these projects have a barely living population.

TF2 exists as a tragedy in 2023. Official servers are ran over by bots. It is to the point that if you see a Sniper, they're most likely a cheater or a bot. This isn't even "wow that Sniper main is so good they get a flattering amount of cheatcusations." This is obvious cheating, where a single Sniper walks into the open, spins like a top, and perfectly headshots every opposing player around them. 

The overwhelming majority of the TF2 community agrees that botting/cheating is bad and there is a gentleman's agreement to kick those cheating from the game. Unfortunately, cheating is so rampant that you are likely to boot a cheater, just to get a new one popping up in its place. Eventually, the players reach critical mass. They don't want to deal with it, so the victims start to leave. Then cheaters fill in for legitimate players on the other team and then they have to play whack-a-mole, too. 

It's a horrible problem that has infested this once beloved game for years.
Don't recommend it, it's just not fun.

This game is infested with cheating bots. You can still find servers with real players, but takes a bit of effort to dodge all the bots. Alternatively, you have the choice of going to community servers. There's never been a worse time to get into the game, but it's the kind of game that can get you hooked and come back to play it occasionally for the rest of your life. It's free to play, try it out.

The majority of players that start playing are children and develop poor spending habits from the free-to-play model. So be careful not to end up like the rest of the people who became gambling addicts or spent over $1000 on the game because they couldn't help themselves. Or if you do spend a lot, have no regrets. I always did love the free-to-play models for being especially effective on children and turning them into life-long customers.
